DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC SERVICES DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1982, adopted January 26, 2009, amended division 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, division 2 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1963, § 1.99, and Ord. No. 1604, adopted December 12, 1994. 

Sec. 2-126. - Departmental responsibility. 
    The public services department shall be responsible for the following functions and duties: 
(1)  Planning in connection with such changes or improvements to the physical properties of the city as are consistent with and necessary to the future growth and development of the city. 
(2)  Works closely with the city engineer in coordinating the various activities of the water supply department. 
(3)  Managing, maintaining and operating the city's equipment pool. 
(4)  Maintaining the water distribution and sewer system. 
(5)  Maintaining streets. 
(6)  Operating and managing solid waste disposal and recycling programs. 
(7)  Developing, managing, maintaining and operating parks, golf courses, ice arena, boulevards and recreation facilities and activities. 
(8)  Enforcing the noxious grass and weed, and Dutch elm disease ordinances. 
(9)  Managing and maintaining the city's forestry resources. 
(Ord. No. 1982, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 2-127. - Department head. 
    The department of public services shall be headed by the director of the department of public services. Except as otherwise expressly provided, the public services director shall oversee all functions and duties set forth in this Code for the public services department and any official or director thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1982, 1-26-09) 
Secs. 2-128-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-141. - Department responsibility. 
    The community development department shall be responsible for the coordination of all planning and building activities in the city and the management of the review, inspection and enforcement activities related to such planning and building activities. The department shall be responsible for making recommendations for the long range overall development of the city, both on a broad policy basis and in the administration of individual projects. Except as otherwise expressly provided, wherever the terms "building department" or "planning department" appear in this Code of Ordinances, they shall be construed to mean the "community development department." 
(Ord. No. 1604, 12-12-94) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1604, adopted December 12, 1994, amended § 2-141. Formerly, such section pertained to department head and derived from §§ 1.102, 1.104 from the 1963 Code. 
Sec. 2-142. - Department head. 
    The community development department shall be headed by the community development director. Except as otherwise expressly provided, the community development director shall oversee all functions and duties set forth in this Code for the building department and planning department and any official or director thereof and all references to "building official" or "planning director" shall be construed to mean the "community development director or his designee." 
(Ord. No. 1604, 12-12-94) 
Secs. 2-143-2-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - HUMAN RESOURCES DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-151. - Departmental responsibility. 
    The human resources department shall be headed by the human resources director. This person shall be responsible to the city manager for employee recruitment and selection activities; employee relations management; and the administration of the city policies as relates to procedures in employment matters. The human resources director is the authorized city representative for offers of employment and in relations with employee organizations. 
Secs. 2-152-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ENGINEERING 

Sec. 2-171. - Departmental responsibility. 
    The engineering department shall be responsible for the following functions and duties: 
(1)  Issuing all permits and inspecting of all work involved in the construction and management of sidewalks, curb cuts, rights-of-way, parking structures, sewers and water mains. 
(2)  Performing or providing such engineering services for the city and for such other departments of the city as may be required. 
(3)  Administering capital improvement projects as may be needed to maintain the continuing functional value of the water and sewer systems, street and sidewalk systems, parking system and street lighting system. 
(4)  Managing the city's parking operations contractor and providing administrative support to the advisory parking committee. 
(5)  Manage and coordinate outside utility companies operating within the city. 
(6)  Establish and collect the appropriate fees as may be required by the department for various engineering services from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1982, 1-26-09; Ord. No. 2055, 6-14-10) 
Sec. 2-172. - Superintendent of water supply department. 
    The city engineer shall act as the superintendent of the water supply department, supervising and coordinating the various activities of that department. Whenever the phrase "superintendent of the water supply department" is used in this Code, it shall be synonymous with the city engineer and shall refer to the one and the same official, the head of the engineering department. 
(Ord. No. 1982, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 2-173. - Street administrator. 
    The city engineer shall act as the superintendent of streets; supervising and coordinating all activities within the rights-of-way with all local, regional, state and federal agencies. 
(Ord. No. 1982, 1-26-09)

DIVISION 2. - HOUSING COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Housing code, § 22-256 et seq. 

Sec. 2-181. - Created. 
    Pursuant to Act No. 18 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1933, Extra Session (MCL 125.651 et seq.), as amended, a commission is hereby created in and for the city to be known as the Birmingham Housing Commission. 
(Code 1963, § 1.311) 
Sec. 2-182. - Members; terms; compensation. 
    The city manager is hereby directed to appoint, with the approval of the city commission, the members of the housing commission. Each member of the commission shall be appointed for a term of five years. Members of the first commission shall be appointed for the terms of one year, two years, three years, four years and five years respectively; and annually thereafter one member shall be appointed for the term of five years. Members of the commission shall serve without compensation and may be removed from office by the appointing authority. Any vacancy in office shall be filled by the appointing authority for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1963, § 1.312) 
Sec. 2-183. - Powers. 
    The housing commission shall have all of the powers and duties vested or permitted to be vested in housing commissions by Act No. 18 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1933, Extra Session (MCL 125.651 et seq.), as amended, and any laws enacted which are supplemental thereto, it being the intention of this section to vest in the housing commission all powers and duties permitted by law. 
(Code 1963, § 1.313) 
Sec. 2-184. - Meetings; officers. 
    The housing commission shall meet at regular intervals, such meetings to be public. It shall adopt its own rules of procedure, and shall keep a record of the proceedings. Three members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. A president and vice-president shall be elected by the commission. The commission may appoint a director who may also serve as secretary, and such other employees or officers as shall be necessary. The commission shall prescribe the duties of all of its officers and employees and may, with the approval of the city manager, fix their compensation. The commission may from time to time, as necessary and with the approval of the city commission, employ engineers, architects and consultants. 
(Code 1963, § 1.314) 
Sec. 2-185. - Finances. 
    Funds for the operation of the housing commission may be provided by the city commission but the commission shall as soon as possible reimburse the city for all monies expended by it for the commission from revenues received from the sale of bonds. 
(Code 1963, § 1.315) 
Sec. 2-186. - Reports. 
    The housing commission shall make an annual report of its activities to the city commission and shall make such other reports as the city commission may from time to time require. 
(Code 1963, § 1.316) 
Secs. 2-187-2-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF REVIEW[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1981, adopted January 26, 2009, amended division 3 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, division 3 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1963, §§ 1.45, 1.46, and Ord. No. 1575, § 1.47, adopted December 13, 1993. 

Sec. 2-196. - Board of review. 
(a)  Appointment; term. The city commission shall appoint a board of review for the city. Members of the board of review shall be property tax payers and electors in the city and shall serve for terms of three years. Each member of the board of review shall qualify by taking the constitutional oath of office within ten days after appointment. Each member shall attend at least one state board of review update educational seminar annually, prior to the organizational meeting provided for in subsection (d)(1). The city commission may fill any vacancy that occurs in the membership of the board of review. Except as otherwise provided in this division, the duties and responsibilities of the board of review shall be carried out by the entire membership and a majority of the membership constitutes a quorum for such purposes. A spouse, mother, father, sister, brother, son, or daughter, including an adopted child, of the assessor is not eligible to serve as a regular or alternate member or to fill any vacancy. 
(b)  Number of boards and members. The city commission may appoint three or six property taxpayers and electors of the city, who shall constitute a board of review for the city. If six members are appointed, the membership of the board of review shall be divided into board of review committees consisting of three members each for the purposes of hearing and deciding issues protested by taxpayers. Two of the three members of a board of review committee constitute a quorum for the transaction of the business of the committee. All meetings of the members of the board of review and committees shall be held during the same hours of the day and at the same location. A majority of the entire board of review membership shall indorse the assessment roll. 
(c)  Alternate members. The city commission may appoint not more than two alternate members for the same term as the regular members of the board of review. Each alternate member shall be a property taxpayer and elector of the city. Alternate members shall qualify by taking the constitutional oath of office within ten days after appointment. Each alternate member shall attend at least one state board of review update educational seminar annually, prior to the organizational meeting provided for in subsection (d)(1) below. The city commission may fill any vacancy that occurs in the alternate membership of the board of review. A member of the city commission is not eligible to serve as an alternate member or to fill any vacancy. An alternate member may be called to perform the duties of a regular member of the board of review in the absence of a regular member. An alternate member may also be called to perform the duties of a regular member of the board of review for the purpose of reaching a decision on issues protested in which a regular member has abstained for reasons of conflict of interest. 
(d)  Meetings. 
(1)  Organizational meeting. The board of review shall hold an organizational meeting on the Tuesday following the first Monday in March of each year. 
(2)  Starting and subsequent meetings. The board of review starting date shall be the second Monday in March. This meeting shall not start earlier than 9:00 a.m. and not later than 3:00 p.m., and shall last for not less than six hours. The board of review shall also meet for not less than six hours during the remainder of that week. Persons or agents who have properly appeared to file a protest before the board of review at a scheduled meeting or at a scheduled appointment as required in this division shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard by the board of review. The board of review shall hold at least three hours of its required sessions for review of assessment rolls after 6:00 p.m. during the week of the second Monday in March. 
(3)  Final meeting. The board of review shall schedule a final meeting after the board of review makes a change in the assessed value or tentative taxable value of property or adds property to the assessment roll. 
(4)  July and December meetings. The board of review shall hold a special meeting during the week of the third Monday in July and during the week of the second Monday in December of the tax year at issue. The board of review shall address and take actions on only those matters permitted by statute for these meetings. 
(Ord. No. 1981, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 2-197. - Completion of review. 
    The city assessment roll and the final review thereof shall be completed not later than the first Monday in April of each year. 
(Ord. No. 1981, 1-26-09) 
Sec. 2-198. - Protests to board of review. 
(a)  Protests to the board of review may be made in person in accordance with this section. Additionally, the board of review shall permit both resident and nonresident taxpayers to protest to the board of review in writing, without the necessity of a personal appearance by the taxpayer or the taxpayer's representative, provided such written protest is received on or before the last date and time indicated on the assessment notice, or such later date as the board of review may specify. 
(b)  The board of review shall accept appointments from taxpayers or their representatives to appear and protest in person from the date assessment change notices are sent by the city, through the last date and time listed on the assessment notice of the tax year at issue, or such later date as the board of review may specify. 
(c)  Before hearing or considering a protest, whether made in person or in writing, by a person or representative other than the taxpayer of record, an original letter of authority, signed and dated by the taxpayer of record, shall be submitted authorizing such person or representative to protest to the board of review on the taxpayer's behalf. This requirement shall be stated on the city's assessment change notices. Faxed or emailed appeals or letters of authority shall not be accepted. 
(d)  All protests to the board of review shall be made in compliance with state law. 
(e)  Each person who makes a request, protest or application to the board of review for the correction of the assessed value or tentative taxable value of the person's property shall be notified in writing of the board of review's action on the request, protest, or application, of the state equalized valuation or tentative taxable value of the property, and of information regarding the right to further appeal to the tax tribunal including, but not limited to, a statement of the right to appeal to the tax tribunal, the address of the tax tribunal, and the final date for filing an appeal with the tax tribunal. Said notice shall be sent not later than the first Monday in June. 
(Ord. No. 1981, 1-26-09) 
Secs. 2-199-2-205. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-206. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RETIREMENT SYSTEM 

Sec. 2-207. - Continuation of retirement system. 
    The retirement system of the city as originally established by Charter in 1944, as amended from time to time, and completely restated effective July 1, 1992, is hereby continued. All existing participants shall retain all service and account balances accrued to July 1, 1992. Provisions of this division shall not apply to any participant who terminated employment with the city prior to its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.700, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-208. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from a member's compensation and credited to the member's individual account in the reserve for members' contributions, together with interest thereon as allocated by the retirement board. 
    Beneficiary means an individual who is being paid or is entitled to the future payment of a retirement allowance for any reason other than the individual's membership in the retirement system. 
    City means the City of Birmingham, Michigan, and shall include its several officers and departments and the public library established in chapter XVI of the Charter. 
    Compensation means the salary or wages paid to an employee for personal services rendered to the city while a member of the retirement system. Salary and wages shall include longevity pay; overtime pay; cost of living allowances; shift differentials; pay for periods of absence from work by reason of employer approved vacation, holiday and sickness; and deferred compensation amounts under deferred compensation programs recognized by the city commission. Compensation shall not include any remuneration or reimbursement not specifically stated to be included, such as allowances for clothing, equipment, cleaning and travel; reimbursement of expenses; bonuses; termination or severance pay; payments in consideration of unused vacation or sick leave; and the value of any fringe benefit. 
    Credited service means service credited to a member by the retirement board to the extent provided by this division. 
    Final average compensation means the highest average annual compensation received by a member during a period of three consecutive years of service contained within his last ten years of service immediately preceding retirement. If he has less than three years of credited service, his final average compensation shall be the average of his annual compensations received during his total years of credited service. 
    Fire member means any officer or employee in the fire department of the city holding the rank of firefighter, including probationary firefighter, or higher rank. The term "fire member" shall not include: 
(1)  Any civilian employee in the fire department; 
(2)  Any person temporarily employed in the fire department for an emergency; and 
(3)  Any person privately employed as a firefighter. 
    Full-time employee means any person who receives compensation from the city in a position that is normally compensated for at least 2,080 hours of service a year. 
    General member means any member, except a police or fire member. 
    Interest means such rate of interest per year, compounded annually, as the board shall from time to time determine. 
    Member means any person included in the membership of the retirement system under this division 2 and not persons who are participants in any other retirement plan governed by the provisions of division 3, division 4 or otherwise. 
    Part-time employee means any person who receives compensation from the city in a position that is normally compensated for at least 1,040 hours of service a year, but less than 2,080 hours of service a year. 
    Police member means any officer or employee in the police department of the city holding the rank of patrol officers, including probationary patrol officers, or higher rank. The term "police member" shall not include: 
(1)  Any civilian employee in the police department; 
(2)  Any person temporarily employed in the police department for an emergency; and 
(3)  Any person privately employed as a police officer. 
    Retired member means a person who is paid a retirement allowance on account of their membership in the retirement system. 
    Retirement means a member's withdrawal from city employment with a retirement allowance payable by the retirement system. 
    Retirement allowance means a series of monthly payments payable by the retirement system throughout the future lifetime of a person or for a temporary period as may be provided by ordinance. 
    Retirement board or board means the retirement board provided for in this division. 
    Service means service rendered to the city by an officer or employee of the city while a member of the retirement system and qualifying military service. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.701, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1910, 3-19-07) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-209. - Retirement board-Established, members. 
(a)  The retirement board as created in chapter XIX of the city Charter as originally adopted on April 3, 1944, and restated in its entirety effective July 1, 1992, shall be continued. Such board shall have the power to administer, manage, and properly operate the retirement system, and to make effective the provisions of this division. The board shall consist of seven voting trustees as follows: 
(1)  The mayor. 
(2)  A city commissioner to be selected by the city commission and to serve at the pleasure of the city commission. 
(3)  The city manager. 
(4)  A citizen, who is an elector of the city, and who is not eligible to participate in the retirement system as a member or retired member, to be appointed by the mayor by and with the consent of the city commission. 
(5)  A police member to be elected by the police members. 
(6)  A fire member to be elected by the fire members. 
(7)  A general member to be elected by the general members. 
(b)  In addition, there shall be one nonvoting ex officio retired member/beneficiary member to be elected by the retired members and beneficiaries currently receiving benefits from the system. If more than one beneficiary is receiving a retirement allowance or other benefit from the retirement system attributable to the service of one former member or retired member, such beneficiaries shall be entitled to a single vote on behalf of the former member or retired member. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.702, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-210. - Same-Terms of office. 
    The members of the retirement board provided for in section 2-209 shall be elected under such rules and regulations as the board shall adopt to govern such elections. The term of office of the board members provided for in section 2-209 shall expire at the end of each three-year period following July 1, 1993, for the appointed citizen board member; July 1, 1995, for the police board member; July 1, 1994, for the fire board member; and July 1, 1993, for the general board member. Except as provided in this section, board members serving at the time of the adoption of a Charter amendment shall complete their current terms. The ex officio retired member/beneficiary member shall be elected for a three-year term which shall commence on July 1, 1992. Each board member shall, within ten days after his appointment or election, as the case may be, take an oath of office, on the form now prescribed by Charter, to be administered by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.703, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-211. - Same-Vacancy on board. 
    If an elected employee board member shall cease to be an employee of the city, or if the citizen member shall move from the city, or if the appointed citizen member or any elected board member shall fail to attend scheduled meetings of the board for three consecutive meetings, unless in each case excused for cause by the remaining board members attending such meetings, he shall be considered to have resigned from the board and the board shall by resolution declare his office vacated as of the adoption of such resolution. If a vacancy occurs in the office of the citizen board member, the mayor shall within 60 days of the date of the vacancy, fill the vacancy by appointment for the unexpired term; such appointment to be made by and with the consent of the city commission. If a vacancy occurs in the office of an elected member, an election shall be held within 60 days of the date of the vacancy to fill the vacancy for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.704, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-212. - Same-Conduct of meetings. 
    The retirement board shall hold meetings regularly, at least one in each quarter year, and shall designate the time and place thereof. Five members of the board shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board. Each voting board member shall be entitled to one vote in the meetings of the board and at least five concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the board members at any meeting of the board. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the board shall be public. The board members shall serve without compensation for their services as such. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.705, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-213. - Same-Officers. 
(a)  Officers of the retirement board shall be a chairman and a vice-chairman elected by the board from its own number. 
(b)  The city treasurer shall be secretary of the retirement system. The secretary shall keep, or cause to be kept, such data as shall be necessary for an actuarial valuation of the assets and liabilities of the retirement system. 
(c)  The city treasurer shall be treasurer of the retirement system. All payments from funds of the retirement system shall be authorized by the city treasurer at the direction of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.706, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-214. - Same-Responsibilities. 
(a)  The retirement board shall administer the system in accordance with the Charter and the terms of this division. 
(b)  The board shall render a report to the city commission showing the fiscal transactions of the retirement system for the year ending the preceding June 30 and the last balance sheet showing the financial condition of the retirement system by means of an actuarial valuation of the assets and liabilities of the retirement system as of the preceding June 30. 
(c)  The board shall adopt such mortality and other tables of experience as are necessary in the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis. 
(d)  The board may appoint an actuary who shall be the technical advisor to the board on matters regarding the operation of the retirement system and who shall perform such other duties as are required in connection therewith. 
(e)  The board may appoint a medical director who shall not be eligible to participate in the retirement system as a member, beneficiary or retired member. The medical director shall be responsible to and shall hold office at the pleasure of the board. He shall arrange for and pass upon all medical examinations required under this division. He shall investigate all essential statements and certificates of a medical nature made by or on behalf of a member or retired member; and he shall report in writing to the board his conclusions on medical matters referred to him by the board. 
(f)  The board may employ such professional and clerical services as are required for the proper operation of the retirement system. The compensation for such services shall be fixed by the board. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.707, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-215. - Applicability of division. 
(a)  The terms of the retirement allowances as set forth in this division shall apply only to those members retiring after July 1, 1992. This division shall not apply to persons first employed by the city on or after January 1, 2007. Except as provided in this section, nothing in this division shall be construed to increase or decrease the retirement allowances of any retired member who retired after July 1, 1992. A roster of current retired members and their level of benefits shall be available at the office of the treasurer for inspection by the public during business hours. 
(b)  The retirement allowance of retired members who retired prior to July 1, 1992, or any beneficiary of such retired member may be increased by an amount established by a five-sevenths vote of the city commission. 
(c)  For all retired members who retired prior to July 1, 1992, or any beneficiary of such retired member, a minimum retirement allowance is established for all monthly payments made after July 1, 1992, which shall equal $20.00 per month per year of credited service and fraction thereof. However, such amount shall be actuarially reduced to provide a lesser proportional benefit to retired members or their beneficiaries who selected an optional form of benefit at their retirement date. 
(d)  For all retired members who retired prior to May 1, 1998, or any beneficiary of such retired member, a minimum retirement allowance is established for all monthly payments made after May 1, 1998, which shall equal $40.00 per month per year of credited service and fraction thereof. However, such amount shall be actuarially reduced to provide a lesser proportional benefit to retired members or their beneficiaries who selected an optional form of benefit at their retirement date. 
(e)  The city commission may, by a five-sevenths vote, revoke or reduce such minimum payment. In no instance shall the amount of the benefit payable to such retired member or any beneficiary of such retired member be reduced from the amount being received at the time of passage of this division except when such reduction is based on the retired member's exercise of one of the options available at the time of such member's retirement. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.709, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1565, § 1.709, 6-29-93; Ord. No. 1670, 3-23-98; Ord. No. 1910, 3-19-07) 
Sec. 2-216. - Membership of system. 
(a)  An employee who was a member on June 30, 1992, shall be a member on July 1, 1992. On or after July 1, 1992, an employee shall become a member on the date such employee is first employed by the city and is otherwise eligible for membership provided, that employees hired on or after January 1, 2007 (or such later date as may be set forth in any applicable collective bargaining agreement between a bargaining unit and the city) shall not become members of the retirement system. 
(b)  The membership of the retirement system shall include all persons paid compensation for personal services rendered to the city, but it shall not include: 
(1)  Any person whose services are compensated on a fee basis; 
(2)  Any person whose time of service in a period of three consecutive years averages less than a certain number of hours per year which number shall be established by the board by resolution; 
(3)  The medical director or actuary; 
(4)  Elective officials; 
(5)  Any person who is employed on a basis that exempts the city from the withholding provisions of the Internal Revenue Code; nor 
(6)  Any person who becomes a participant in any other retirement system or retirement plan maintained by the city, unless specifically authorized by ordinance. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided in this division, if a member terminates employment with the city or dies, he shall cease to be a member. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this division, if a member terminates employment with the city, for any reason except his retirement, disability, or death, and is thereafter reemployed by the city, he shall recommence membership on the date he satisfies the conditions of membership. If reemployment occurs within three years of the member's last day of service, his credited service forfeited by him shall be restored to this credit subject to the provisions of subsection 2-237(d), except for military service, as provided in section 2-218. If the reemployment occurs three or more years after the member's last day of service, he shall be treated as a new hire and will not become a member of the retirement system. 
(e)  The board shall credit each member's service account with the number of years and months of service to which he may be entitled. 
(f)  In all cases of doubt, the board shall decide who is a member within the meaning of the provisions of this division and the classification of such member. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.708, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1910, 3-19-07) 
Sec. 2-217. - Years of service. 
    The retirement board shall fix and determine by rules and regulations the number of years and months of service to be credited each member for his employment as a member in accordance with the following: 
(1)  No less than 15 days of service in a calendar month shall constitute a month of service. 
(2)  A day of service shall include: 
a.  Any day for which a member receives compensation for four or more hours of work; and 
b.  Any day for which a member is receiving compensation directly from the city due to accumulated sick leave, personal days or vacation time, regardless of the percentage of the member's normal rate of compensation that is paid for such time. 
(3)  For purposes of computing the retirement allowance of a member with service both as a full-time and a part-time employee, the member's part-time service shall be multiplied by the ratio of his average annual hours of part-time service to 2,080. 
(4)  No more than one year of service shall be credited to any member for service rendered in one calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.710, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-218. - Military service credit. 
(a)  A member who leaves or left city employment to enter any armed service of the United States and who has been or shall be on active duty, shall have periods of active duty credited as city service subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The member shall be reemployed by the city within 90 days from and after termination of his required service or from hospitalization continuing after discharge for a period of not more than one year. 
(2)  The member shall return to the reserve for members' contributions all amounts withdrawn therefrom at the time he entered or while in such armed service, together with regular interest thereon from the date of withdrawal to the date of repayment. 
(b)  In any case of doubt as to the period to be credited a member, the board shall have final power to determine such period, however, in no case shall more than six years of service be credited to a member for military service. During the period of such military service, and until his return to city service, the member shall have the option to continue to make payments to the reserve for members' contributions as if he had continued employment or on reinstatement, he may repay any such contributions which were not paid during such period of military service. If the member chooses to make such contributions, the city shall make employer contributions on the member's behalf as would have been made had his employment been uninterrupted. Regardless of whether the member chooses to make such contributions, the balance in his reserve for members' contributions shall be accumulated with interest at a rate to be established by the board. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.711, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-219. - Service account. 
    The retirement board shall credit each member's service account with the number of years and months of prior service and credited service to which he is entitled. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.712, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-220. - Application for retirement. 
    Any member who has attained or will attain his normal retirement age within 90 days may file his written application for retirement with the board. Such application shall set forth the date the member desires to be retired, however, such date shall not be less than 30 nor more than 90 days subsequent to the execution and filing of the application. No person shall retire prior to attaining his normal retirement age. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.713, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-221. - Mandatory retirement. 
(a)  Any police or fire member who has attained or attains age 60 years shall be separated from city service on the first day of the calendar month next following the month in which he attains age 60. 
(b)  Any police or fire member who has attained his mandatory retirement age as provided in subsection (a) of this section may be continued in service for periods not to extend beyond his attainment of age 70 years; provided, that no such extension shall be granted unless it is: 
(1)  Requested in writing by the same member, 
(2)  Approved by his department head, and 
(3)  Approved by the city manager. 
(c)  If, at the time of his separation from service as provided in this section, a member has ten or more years of credited service, he shall be retired and he shall receive a retirement allowance provided for in section 2-225. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.714, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-222. - Benefit groups. 
(a)  The following benefit groups are designated for the purpose of determining benefit conditions, benefit amounts and contribution amounts applicable to a member: 
(1)  Fire members shall be divided into the following subgroups: 
a.  Benefit group fire shall consist of all members who are represented by Birmingham Firefighters Association Local 911 affiliated with the Michigan State Firefighters Union, the International Association of Firefighters and the Michigan AFL-CIO, and the Metropolitan Detroit AFL-CIO Labor Council. 
b.  Benefit group fire command shall consist of the fire chief, assistant chief and fire marshal. 
c.  Benefit group fire DC members shall consist of firefighters hired on or after April 1, 2012. 
(2)  General members shall be divided into the following subgroups: 
a.  Benefit group AFSCME shall consist of all members who are represented by Local 998, Birmingham Clerical Employees Chapter affiliated with International Union, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and Council No. 25. 
b.  Benefit group general shall consist of all members not included in other benefit groups, including all nonunion members not specifically provided for in this section. 
c.  Benefit group library shall consist of all members who are employees of the library as maintained under Chapter XVI of the City Charter. 
d.  Benefit group police support shall consist of all members who are police dispatchers and paraprofessionals and are represented by the Birmingham Police Officers Association affiliated with the Police Officers Association of Michigan. 
e.  Benefit group teamsters shall consist of all members who are represented by Teamsters State, County and Municipal Workers Union, Local 214, affiliated with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America. 
f.  Benefit group executive members shall consist of the city manager. 
g.  Benefit group police support DC members shall consist of police support members hired on or after July 1, 2011. 
(3)  Police members shall be divided into the following subgroups: 
a.  Benefit group command shall consist of all members who are represented by the Birmingham Command Officers Association affiliated with the Command Officers Association of Michigan. 
b.  Benefit group police shall consist of all members who are sworn police officers and are represented by the Birmingham Police Officers Association affiliated with the Police Officers Association of Michigan but shall not include police dispatchers and paraprofessionals. 
c.  Benefit group police officials shall consist of the chief of police and the captain. 
d.  Benefit group police DC members shall consist of police officers hired on or after July 1, 2011. 
e.  Benefit group command DC members shall consist of command officers hired on or after July 1, 2011. 
(b)  Age and service conditions for eligibility and rate of benefits shall be those applicable to the member's benefit group at the time of termination of membership. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.715, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1527, 7-13-92; Ord. No. 1744, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12)

    The normal retirement date of a member shall be the date he attains his normal retirement age. Normal retirement age shall be determined in accordance with the following table:

Sec. 2-224. - Reduced early retirement. 
(a)  A member who is in benefit group teamsters who is at least age 55, but less than age 60, and who has ten or more years of service may elect to take an actuarially reduced retirement allowance commencing at any age after he reaches his 55th birthday but prior to his 60th birthday; the actuarial reduction shall be one-half of one percent per month for each month the employee is less than age 60; the benefit to be actuarially reduced shall be the benefit the employee is eligible for based on his service and final average compensation as of the date he elects retirement under this section. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a member who is in benefit group teamsters who is at least age 50, but less than age 60, and who has 30 years or more of service may elect to retire at full benefit levels (i.e., with no actuarial reduction for retirement prior to normal retirement age) during the periods between November 1, 1992, to March 31, 1993, and October 1, 1994, to December 31, 1994. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.717, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1573, § 1.717, 10-11-93; Ord. No. 1744, 8-28-00) 
Sec. 2-225. - Retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon his retirement, a member, other than police DC members, command DC members and police support DC members hired on or after July 1, 2011 and fire DC members hired on or after April 1, 2012, who has attained his normal retirement age, shall receive a regular retirement allowance. Prior to retirement, he may elect to receive his retirement allowance under an option provided in section 2-227 in lieu of a regular retirement allowance. His regular retirement allowance shall be equal to the number of years, and fraction of a year, of his credited service multiplied by the applicable percentage of his final average compensation. A member who is in benefit group executive members, upon his retirement, who has attained his normal retirement age, shall receive a regular retirement allowance. His regular retirement allowance shall be equal to the highest percentage of final average compensation in effect between the city and any of its collective bargaining units during the term of his contract with the city, but in no event less than 2.85 percent, multiplied by all years of service from employee's original date of hire. Police DC members, command DC members and police support DC members hired on or after July 1, 2011 and fire DC members hired on or after April 1, 2012 shall not receive a regular retirement allowance under the provisions of the Birmingham Employee Retirement System.

(b)  According to such rules and regulations as the board may from time to time adopt, any member covered by social security who retires prior to his attainment of age 65 may elect to have his regular retirement allowance actuarially equated to provide an increased retirement allowance payable to his attainment of age 65 years and a reduced retirement allowance payable thereafter. His increased retirement allowance payable to his attainment of age 65 years shall approximate the sum of his reduced retirement allowance payable to his attainment of age 65 years and his estimated primary social security amount. This subsection shall not be applicable to a retirement allowance payable under an option provided in section 2-227 nor to a retirement allowance payable under section 2-232. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.718, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1573, § 1.718, 10-11-93; Ord. No. 1744, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 1779, 2-25-02; Ord. No. 1785, 7-29-02; Ord. No. 1794, 12-16-02; Ord. No. 1852, 12-13-04; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 2-226. - Deferred retirement. 
(a)  Should any member, who has ten years of service leave the employ of the city prior to the attainment of his normal retirement age for any reason except his retirement or death, he shall be entitled to the retirement allowance set forth below, as in effect at the time the employee terminates employment with the city. Effective September 1, 2000, should any member of the subgroup general and, effective July 1, 2004, should any member of the subgroup library of general members who has seven years of service leave the employ of the city prior to the attainment of his normal retirement age for any reason except his retirement or death, he shall be entitled to the retirement allowance set forth below. Should a member of benefit group executive members leave the employ of the city for any reason other than death or disability retirement, he shall be entitled to the retirement allowance set forth below:

(b)  The deferred retirement allowance shall begin 30 days after the application for same is filed with the board but not prior to the attainment of age 60 if a member of benefit group AFSCME, general, police support or teamsters or age 55 if a member of benefit group command, fire, fire command, police or police official. However, if he withdraws his accumulated contributions from the reserve for members' contributions at the time of his termination of employment for any reason other than death, disability or retirement, he shall thereupon forfeit his right to a deferred retirement allowance provided in this section. Unless otherwise provided in this division, he shall not receive service credit for the period of his absence from city employment. During the period of his absence from city employment and until his retirement allowance begins, his balance in the reserve for members' contributions shall be accumulated with interest as established by the board. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.719, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1573, § 1.719, 10-11-93; Ord. No. 1744, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 1785, 7-29-02; Ord. No. 1852, 12-13-04; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 2-227. - Payment options. 
(a)  Prior to the effective date of his retirement, but not thereafter, a member may elect to receive his retirement allowance as a regular retirement allowance payable throughout his life, or he may elect to receive the actuarial equivalent, at that time, of his regular retirement allowance in a reduced retirement allowance payable throughout his life, and nominate a beneficiary, in accordance with the provisions of Option I, II or III, as set forth in this subsection, subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(1)  Option I. Ten years certain and life option thereafter. If a retired member dies before he has been paid 120 monthly retirement allowance payments, the payments shall be continued for the remainder of the period of 120 months to such person as he shall nominate by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to the effective date of his retirement. If there is no such designated beneficiary surviving the retired member, such remaining monthly payments shall be continued and paid to the estate of the survivor of the retired member or his last surviving beneficiary; 
(2)  Option II. Survivor retirement allowance. Upon the death of a retired member, his reduced retirement allowance shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person as he shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to the effective date of his retirement; or 
(3)  Option III. Modified survivor retirement allowance. Upon the death of a retired member, one-half of his reduced retirement allowance shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person as he shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to the effective date of his retirement. Provided, however, a retired member may elect, by written designation duly executed and filed with the board prior to the effective date of his retirement, that upon his death, either 25 percent or 75 percent of his reduced retirement allowance shall be continued throughout the life of and paid to such person as he shall have nominated. 
(b)  Survivor retirement allowance with pop-up feature. Upon election of Option II or III as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the member may elect a pop-up feature with an additional option election factor adjustment to the factors utilized in computing Options II and III. Under the pop-up feature, upon the death of his named beneficiary prior to the death of the retired member, the amount of the retired member's retirement allowance shall be increased to his unreduced straight life retirement allowance effective with the first day of the month following the death of his named beneficiary. This subsection shall not apply to any member who retired prior to the date of the adoption of this section. 
(c)  If any benefits become payable under section 2-235 on account of the death of a retired member: 
(1)  No retirement allowance shall be paid to his designated survivor beneficiary under Option II or III above, and 
(2)  If his death occurs before he has received in retirement allowance payments an aggregate amount equal to, but not exceeding, his accumulated contributions standing to his credit in the reserve for members' contributions at the time of his retirement, the difference between his accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of retirement allowance payments received by him shall be paid to his designated beneficiary, if living, otherwise to his estate. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.720, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1560, § 1.720, 8-23-93; Ord. No. 1852, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 2-228. - Election of Option II. 
(a)  Any member who continues in the employ of the city after the date he either: 
(1)  Acquires 20 years of credited service, or 
(2)  Attains age 55 years and has ten or more years of credited service, 
may, by written declaration duly executed and filed with the board, elect Option II provided for in section 2-227 and nominate a beneficiary whom the board finds to be dependent upon the member for at least 50 percent of his support, in the same manner as if he were then retiring from service, notwithstanding that the member may not have attained his normal retirement age. Prior to the effective date of his retirement, a member may revoke his election of Option II and nominate a beneficiary as provided in this subsection. Upon the death of a member, who has an Option II election in force, his beneficiary, if living, shall immediately receive the same retirement allowance which the beneficiary would have been entitled to receive had the member retired the day preceding the date of his death, notwithstanding that he may not have attained his normal retirement age. The Option II shall be applied to a retirement allowance computed according to section 2-225 for a beneficiary of a deceased member. If a member has an Option II election in force at the time of his retirement, his election and nomination of beneficiary shall thereafter continue in force, unless prior to the effective date of his retirement, he elects to receive his retirement allowance as a regular retirement allowance or according to an option provided for in section 2-227. No benefits shall be paid under this subsection on account of the death of a member if any benefits are paid under section 2-235 on account of his death. 
(b)  The surviving spouse of a member who continued in the city's employ after attaining either 20 years of credited service or ten years of credited service and age 55 years, and who did not have an Option II election in force at the time of the member's death, shall immediately receive the same benefit as if the member had timely elected an Option II benefit with the surviving spouse as the beneficiary. No benefits shall be paid under this subsection on account of the death of a member if any benefits are paid under section 2-235 on account of his death. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.721, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-229. - Refund of accumulated contributions on death of retired member. 
(a)  If a retired member dies before he has received in regular retirement allowance payments an aggregate amount equal to, but not exceeding the accumulated contributions standing to the retired member's credit in the reserve for members' contributions at the time of his retirement, the difference between his accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of regular retirement allowance payments received by him shall be paid from the reserve for retirement benefit payments to such person as he shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If no such designated person survives the retired member or the beneficiary of a deceased member dies prior to the payment to the retired member and beneficiary of an aggregate amount equal to the accumulated contributions standing to the retired member's credit, such difference shall be paid to his estate. No benefits shall be paid under this subsection on account of the death of a retired member if he was receiving a retirement allowance provided in section 2-235. 
(b)  If a member dies when receiving benefits under Option I, II, or III above and there is no designated person surviving the retired member, the board shall pay to his estate the difference, if any, between the retired member's accumulated funds at the time of his retirement, and the total retirement allowance received by the retired member prior to his death. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.722, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-230. - Disability retirement. 
    Upon the application of a member or his department head, a member, who is in the service of the city, has ten or more years of credited service and has become or becomes totally and permanently incapacitated for duty in the service of the city, by reason of a personal injury or disease, may be retired by the board; provided, that after a medical examination of the member, made by or under the direction of the medical director, the medical director certifies to the board that the member is mentally or physically totally incapacitated for duty in the service of the city, that his incapacity will probably be permanent, and that the member should be retired; provided further, that the report of the medical director is concurred in by the board. Upon his retirement, a member shall receive a disability retirement allowance. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.723, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 2-231. - Credited service for duty disability. 
    Any member, with less than ten years of credited service shall have his credited service increased to ten years for the sole and exclusive purpose only of qualifying for disability retirement as provided in section 2-230, provided that: 
(1)  The board finds his total and permanent incapacity is the natural and proximate result of a personal injury or disease arising out of and in the course of his actual performance of duty in the service of the city, and 
(2)  He is in receipt of worker's compensation on account of his total and permanent incapacity. 
(3)  Police DC members, command DC members and police support DC members hired on or after July 1, 2011 and fire DC members hired on or after April 1, 2012 shall not receive a regular retirement allowance under the provisions of the Birmingham Employee Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.724, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 2-232. - Disability benefits. 
    Upon his retirement on account of disability, as provided in section 2-230, a member, shall receive a primary disability retirement allowance computed according to section 2-225 notwithstanding that he might not have attained his normal retirement age; except that upon the retirement of a Teamster pursuant to this section, his retirement allowance shall be computed according to section 2-225 as in effect prior to July 1, 2001. If the retired member is in receipt of worker's compensation on account of his city employment, then during the period of his work's compensation, as determined by the board, his primary disability retirement allowance shall not exceed the difference between 70 percent of his final average compensation and his weekly worker's compensation award converted to an annual basis; provided, that his primary disability retirement allowance payable to his normal retirement age shall not be less than 20 percent of his final average compensation. His primary disability retirement allowance shall be subject to section 2-234. Prior to his retirement, he may elect to receive his primary disability retirement allowance under an option provided in section 2-227 in lieu of a regular retirement allowance. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.725, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1779, 2-25-02; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 2-233. - Duty disability benefit. 
    If the board finds that a retired member is totally and permanently incapacitated for duty on account of a personal injury or disease occurring as the natural and proximate result of causes arising out of and in the course of his employment with the city, and the retired member is also in receipt of worker's compensation on account of his disability, the following conditions shall apply: 
(1)  For the period from the date of his disability retirement to his attainment of his normal retirement age, if he retired prior to his normal retirement age, he shall receive a duty disability retirement allowance which, when added to his primary disability retirement allowance, will provide a disability retirement allowance equal to 60 percent of his final average compensation; provided, that during the statutory period for payment of his worker's compensation, but in no case beyond his attainment of his normal retirement age, the total of his primary disability retirement allowance, his weekly worker's compensation converted to an annual basis, and his duty disability retirement allowance shall not exceed 70 percent of his final average compensation. His duty disability retirement allowance, if any, shall: 
a.  Be subject to section 2-234, and 
b.  In no case be eligible to an option election provided for in section 2-227. 
(2)  Upon attaining his normal retirement age, the retired member, shall be given service credit for the period he was entitled to a duty disability retirement allowance, and at that time, his primary disability retirement allowance shall be increased to include such additional credited service. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.726, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 2-234. - Disability reexamination. 
(a)  At least once each year during the first five years following the retirement of a member with a disability retirement allowance, and at least once in each three-year period thereafter, the board may, and upon the retired member's application shall, require any disability retired member who has not attained his normal retirement age, to undergo a medical examination to be made by or under the direction of the medical director. Should any disability retired member who has not attained his normal retirement age refuse to submit to such medical examination in any such period, the board may suspend payment of his disability retirement allowance until his withdrawal of such refusal. If such refusal continues for one year, all his rights in and to a disability retirement allowance shall be forfeited by him. If, upon such medical examination of the retired member, the medical director reports to the board that the retired member is physically able and capable of resuming employment with the city, he shall be returned to active service in the employ of the city and his disability retirement allowance shall terminate; provided, the report of the medical director is concurred in by the board. In returning the retired member to active service, reasonable latitude shall be allowed the city in placing him in a position commensurate to his type of work and rate of compensation at the time of his retirement. 
(b)  If a disability retired member who has not attained his normal retirement age, is or becomes engaged in an occupation, business or employment, his disability retirement allowance shall not exceed the difference between his final average compensation and his pay or earnings from such occupation, business or employment. 
(c)  A disability retired member who has been or shall be returned to active service in the employ of the city as provided in this section, shall again become a member of the retirement system and he shall contribute to the retirement system at the rate applicable to his membership classification. His credited service at the time of his retirement shall be restored to full force and effect. He shall be given service credit for the period he was receiving a disability retirement allowance, provided for in this division, if, within such period he was in receipt of worker's compensation on account of total and permanent disability arising out of and in the course of his city employment; otherwise, he shall not be given service credit for such period. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.727, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-235. - Duty death benefits. 
    If a member dies as the result of a personal injury or disease arising solely and exclusively out of and in the course of his employment with the city, or a disability retired member, while in receipt of worker's compensation on account of his city employment, dies prior to his normal retirement age as the result of the same injury or disease for which he was retired, and in either case, such death, injury or disease resulting in death, be found by the board to have been the result of his actual performance of duty in the service of the city, the applicable benefits provided in subsections (1), (2), and (3) of this section shall be paid, subject to subsection (4) of this section, and subject to the condition that the beneficiaries eligible to retirement allowances apply for and are in receipt of worker's compensation on account of the death of the member or retired member. 
(1)  In the case of the death of a member, the accumulated contributions standing to his credit in the reserve for members' contributions at the time of his death shall be paid in accordance with section 2-236. 
(2)  If the deceased individual was covered by social security: 
a.  The surviving spouse shall receive a retirement allowance equal to the surviving spouse's weekly worker's compensation converted to an annual basis. Such surviving spouse's retirement allowance shall begin upon termination of the statutory period for payment of such worker's compensation and shall continue until death. If such worker's compensation benefits are paid in the form of a lump sum, the statutory period shall be the number of months equal to the amount of the lump sum divided by the monthly payment to which the spouse would be entitled if payment was received in monthly payments. 
b.  His unmarried child or children under age 18 years shall each receive a retirement allowance equal to such child's weekly worker's compensation converted to an annual basis. Such child's retirement allowance shall begin upon termination of the statutory period for payment of such child's worker's compensation and shall continue until his attainment of age 18 years, or death, whichever occurs first. If a surviving spouse's retirement allowance is terminated, each such child's retirement allowance shall be increased by an equal share of such surviving spouse's retirement allowance. 
c.  His parents shall each receive a retirement allowance equal to such parent's weekly worker's compensation converted to an annual basis. Such parent's retirement allowance shall begin upon termination of the statutory period for payment of such parent's worker's compensation and shall continue until his death. 
(3)  If the deceased individual was not covered by social security: 
a.  The surviving spouse shall receive a retirement allowance equal to one-third of his final compensation; provided, that during the statutory period of payment of the surviving spouse's worker's compensation, the surviving spouse's retirement allowance shall be reduced by the amount of such weekly worker's compensation converted to annual basis. Upon death, the retirement allowance shall terminate. 
b.  His unmarried child or children under age 18 years shall each receive a retirement allowance of an equal share of one-fourth of his final compensation. If there is no surviving spouse or if the surviving spouse's retirement allowance is terminated, each such child's retirement allowance shall be an equal share of one-half of such final compensation; provided, that in no case shall any such child's retirement allowance exceed one-fourth of such final compensation. During the statutory period for payment of such child's worker's compensation, his retirement allowance shall be reduced by the amount of his weekly worker's compensation converted to an annual basis. Upon any such child's attainment of age 18 years, or death, whichever occurs first, his retirement allowance shall terminate and there shall be a redistribution by the board to the remaining eligible children of such deceased member or retired member, as the case may be. 
c.  His parents shall each receive a retirement allowance equal to one-sixth of his final compensation; provided, that during the statutory period for payment of such parent's worker's compensation, such retirement allowance shall be reduced by the amount of his worker's compensation converted to an annual basis. Upon a parent's death, his retirement allowance shall terminate. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.728, 6-8-92) 
Sec. 2-236. - Refund of accumulated contributions. 
(a)  Should any member cease to be an employee of the city and not be entitled to receive a retirement allowance payable from funds provided by the city, he shall be paid his accumulated contributions as he shall demand in writing on forms furnished by the board. 
(b)  Upon the death of a member, his accumulated contributions at the time of his death shall be paid, except as otherwise provided in this division, to such person as he shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If there be no such designated person surviving the member, his accumulated contributions shall be paid to his estate. 
(c)  A member who is eligible to receive retirement benefits may withdraw the accumulated contributions standing to the member's credit in the reserve for members' contributions, subject to the following: 
(1)  An additional amount equal to the member's contribution to the City of Birmingham Retiree Health Benefits Plan plus the interest that would have been credited if such contributions had been made to the City of Birmingham Employees Retirement System shall be paid to the member from the reserve for employer contributions. 
(2)  The amount of the member's retirement allowance shall be reduced by the actuarial equivalent of the total amount paid to the member from the reserve for members' contributions and the reserve for employer contributions. The amount of the reduction shall be determined based on the mortality assumption adopted by the retirement board and the immediate annuity interest rate published by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation in effect for the month of retirement. 
(d)  The requirements of this section shall not apply to the benefit group police DC members consisting of police officers hired on or after July 1, 2011 or to benefit group police support DC members consisting of dispatchers hired on or after July 1, 2011 or to benefit group command DC members consisting of police command officers hired on or after July 1, 2011 or to benefit group fire DC members consisting of firefighters hired on or after April 1, 2012. 
(Ord. No. 1523, § 1.729, 6-8-92; Ord. No. 1744, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 2076, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2093-1, 6-25-12) 
Sec. 2-237. - Reserve for members' contributions. 
(a)  There shall be a reserve for members' contributions. It shall be the fund in which the contributions deducted from the compensations of members shall be accumulated with interest, and from which shall be paid refunds of accumulated contributions. 
(b)  Members shall make contributions to the retirement system at the following percentages of their annual compensation:
