ARTICLE III. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-116 et seq. 

Sec. 54-51. - Organization. 
    The fire department shall be headed by the fire chief, who shall be charged with the extinguishment of fires, the protection of life and property against fire, emergency medical services, and the performance of other public services of an emergency nature assigned to it. The fire chief shall also be responsible for administration and management of state and federal emergency preparedness programs relative to the city. 
(Code 1963, § 1.91) 
Sec. 54-52. - Bureau of fire prevention. 
    The bureau of fire prevention shall be a division of the fire department and shall be headed by the fire chief or his designee. This bureau shall be responsible for the prevention of fires, the removal of fire hazards and the conducting of an educational fire prevention program. 
(Code 1963, § 1.92; Ord. No. 2069, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 54-53. - Fire marshal. 
    With the approval of the city commission and the city manager, the fire chief is hereby authorized to appoint the chief fire marshal and such number of deputy fire marshals as may be required for the proper performance of the bureau's duties and responsibilities; such chief fire marshal and all deputies to hold office at the discretion of the fire chief. 
(Code 1963, § 1.93) 
Sec. 54-54. - Inspectors. 
    The fire chief is hereby authorized to appoint from his department such number of inspectors as may in his judgment be required for the proper performance of the bureau's duties and responsibilities and such inspectors to hold office at the discretion of the fire chief. 
(Code 1963, § 1.94) 
Secs. 54-55-54-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COLLECTION OF FEES FOR EMERGENCY MEDICAL AND FIRE SERVICES 

Sec. 54-60. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "emergency service cost recovery ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2024, 3-8-10) 
Sec. 54-61. - Statement of purpose. 
    This article is created to insure that the city shall, to the extent permitted by law, recover the costs of an emergency response from the responsible party. 
(Ord. No. 2024, 3-8-10) 
Sec. 54-62. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the words and phrases listed below shall have the following meanings: 
    Costs of the emergency response shall mean the costs incurred in responding to an emergency event, except as may be limited by a policy adopted by the governing body. Costs include, labor, equipment usage, and materials associated with investigation, removal, repair, abatement, mitigation, monitoring, cleanup, analysis, collection costs and attorney fees. 
    Emergency response shall mean any response by the fire department, entity operating at the request of the fire department, emergency medical service or any other responder as set forth in the National Incident Management System (Homeland Security Presidential Directive 5), to any call, including medical emergencies, for assistance from any person, property owner, government agency, emergency service provider, or other entity. 
    Hazardous materials response shall mean any response to an event involving any chemical, substance, compound, mixture, or other material defined as, designated as, listed as, or having the same characteristics as any substance, compound, mixture or material listed as hazardous under federal or state law or regulation. 
    Person shall mean any individual, partnership, corporation, limited liability corporation, association, consortium, governmental entity, or any other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 2024, 3-8-10) 
Sec. 54-63. - Liability for expense of emergency response. 
(a)  Any owner, lessor, lessee, or operator of any property who is responsible for, or contributes to an emergency response shall be liable for the expense of the emergency response. 
(b)  Any registered owner, lessor, lessee, or operator of any motor vehicle, the operation of which results in an emergency response, shall be liable for the expense of the emergency response. 
(c)  Any public or private utility whose activities or facilities necessitated an emergency response shall be liable for the expense of the emergency response. 
(d)  Any person owning, maintaining or operating a railroad shall be liable for the expense of the emergency response. 
(e)  When an emergency response directly benefits more than one person or property, each person and/or property benefited shall be jointly and severally liable for the payment of the expense of the emergency response. For purposes of an emergency response involving a motor vehicle, occupants other than the operator and the registered owner shall not be liable for the expense of the emergency response. 
(f)  Cost recovery for any hazardous materials response may be pursued in a civil action, pursuant to the Natural Resource Environmental Protection Act (MCL 324.20135(1)(b)). 
(g)  Any person whose activities or condition necessitated transportation from the city emergency medical services, shall be liable for the expense of that transportation. 
(Ord. No. 2024, 3-8-10) 
Sec. 54-64. - Collection and billing of emergency response costs. 
    Collection recovery costs incurred by the city, including billing and collections costs, court costs, and attorney fees, shall be assessed to a responsible party who fails to remit reimbursement for the costs of the provided emergency services in accordance with the billing procedures of this article. 
    Upon a determination of responsibility for an emergency response, the fire chief, or his/her designee, shall prepare and deliver an invoice of the charges imposed to the responsible party or parties for payment. The responsible party shall reimburse the city, as directed by the invoice, for the charges set forth in the invoice within 30 days. The responsible party shall be liable for any costs associated with the collection of the unpaid balance that remains after the expiration of 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 2024, 3-8-10) 
Sec. 54-65. - Severability. 
    If any subsection, clause, phrase, or portion of this article is, for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent portion of this article, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2024, 3-8-10) 
Sec. 54-66. - Savings. 
    All proceedings pending and all rights and liabilities existing, acquired or incurred at the time this article takes effect are saved and may be consummated according to the law in force when they are commenced. 
(Ord. No. 2024, 3-8-10) 
Chapter 58 - HEALTH AND SANITATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1-58-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26. 

Sec. 58-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bactericidal treatment means the application of any method or substance for the destruction of disease producing bacteria as far as practicable which, in the opinion of the health officer is effective and does not affect the equipment, the food and beverages, or the health of the consumer. 
    Baked goods store means a food establishment where baked goods are offered for sale. 
    Bakery means any place where baked goods are processed and which may be offered for sale or delivery. 
    Bakery wagon or truck means any wagon, truck, or other vehicle used for the sale or delivery of baked goods, either on established routes or traveling from house to house. 
    Beverage means any liquid, nutritive material used or intended for human consumption. 
    Caterer means a person who provides food for entertainment at clubs, private homes or social functions, or at shops or other places of employment. This definition shall include the delivery of such food by motor vehicle. 
    Confectionery store means a place where ice cream, carbonated beverages, candy, popcorn and like commodities are sold or prepared for sale or delivery. 
    Dairy store means a place where milk and other milk products are sold. 
    Fish market means a food establishment where fish are sold, prepared for sale or offered for sale or delivery. 
    Food means any solid, nutritive material used or intended for human consumption. 
    Food establishment means any building, vehicle or vending machine where foods or beverages for human consumption are prepared, processed, handled, stored (except the keeping and storing of foods or beverages in the home for the private use of the family), sold or offered for sale or delivered in pursuance of standing orders or other predetermined arrangement or schedule. 
    Food stand means a food establishment where prepared food is sold for consumption, and where customers are not served within the building. 
    Fruit and vegetable market means a food establishment where fruits and vegetables are handled for sale or delivery. 
    Grocery or meat wagon means any wagon, truck or other vehicle used for the sale or delivery of groceries or meat either on established routes or traveling from house to house. 
    Grocery store or grocery means a place where green goods, fruit, vegetables, packaged food, canned food, coffee, tea, spices and staple goods commonly called groceries are sold or kept for sale. 
    Health officer means the city health officer or his duly authorized representative, including employees designated as sanitarians. 
    Ice cream truck means a wagon, truck or other vehicle used for the sale or delivery of ice cream, either on an established route or traveling from house to house. 
    Meat market means a food establishment where dressed meats and meat food products are sold or prepared for sale or offered for sale or delivery. 
    Poultry market means a place where poultry and game are sold or prepared for sale or offered for sale or delivery. 
    Restaurant means a public eating or drinking establishment deemed to include any kitchen where foods or beverages are prepared and/or sold on the premises or any place where foods or beverages are prepared for sale elsewhere. 
    Utensils means any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, containers or other equipment with which food or beverages come in contact during storage, preparation or serving. 
    Vending machine means a machine used for the storage and sale of any food or beverage, except that machines storing and dispensing nonperishable foods and beverages in sealed or capped bottles or packages shall not be deemed included within this definition. 
    Wholesaler means a person who engages in the business of selling food to retailers or jobbers rather than consumers. 
(Code 1963, § 6.1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-27. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the health officer and his representative to enforce the provisions of this article and any official rules or regulations in connection therewith promulgated by the health officer. It shall likewise be the duty of all police officers of the city to assist in the enforcement of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The health officer or his authorized representatives or any police officer shall have the authority to seize any wagon, truck or other vehicle used in the sale, distribution, or delivery of food at retail in the city and which under the provisions of this article is required to be licensed, when such vehicle fails to have its license plate conspicuously displayed thereon as provided in this article. Any vehicle so seized may be impounded by such enforcing officer and held until the owner or operator thereof provides and displays the required license plate. The city or its representatives shall not be liable for any spoilage of food products in such vehicle arising from such impounding. The owner or operator of any vehicle seized for failure to display a license shall pay an impounding fee as set by the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance. 
(Code 1963, § 6.30; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 58-28. - Inspection. 
    The power to enforce the provisions of this article shall be, and the same is, vested in the health officer and his authorized representatives and it shall be the duty of such persons to visit and inspect at frequent intervals every place where food and beverages intended for consumption by human beings are manufactured, kept, stored, prepared, or offered for sale or other disposition; provided, that the police chief and his duly authorized assistants shall assist the department of health in the enforcement of this article when requested to do so by the health officer. 
(Code 1963, § 6.28) 
Sec. 58-29. - Right of entry. 
(a)  The health officer and his authorized representatives and any police officer of the city shall have full power at all times to enter any building, room, basement or vehicle occupied or used, or which they have reasonable cause to believe is being used for the production, preparation, storage, sale or distribution of food or beverages, for the purpose of inspecting the premises and the utensils and equipment used therein. If, upon inspection, any food producing or distributing establishment, employee, employer, clerk, driver or other person is found to be violating any provisions of this article, or if the production, preparation, manufacturing, packing, storing, sale, distribution, or transportation of any such food products is being conducted in a manner detrimental to the health of the employees and operatives or injurious to the quality of such food therein being produced, manufactured, packed, stored, sold or distributed, the officer or sanitarian making such examination or inspection shall thereupon issue an order or rule to the person in authority or in charge of such licensed establishment directing that the condition be remedied within such reasonable time as in his discretion he deems proper. 
(b)  Unless the licensee shall make such improvements as required by such order within the time so limited, it shall be the duty of the health officer to institute proceedings against the person for the violation of this article and/or recommend to the city manager that the license be suspended until such improvements and repairs shall have been made, and approved by the health officer. 
(c)  Should the insanitary condition found warrant such action, the establishment may be immediately closed by the sanitarian making the inspection, in which case he shall notify the person in charge of the establishment at the time of inspection, in writing, stating his reasons for closing the place and a continuance to operate after receiving such a notice shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 6.29) 
Sec. 58-30. - License required; fees; special use permit. 
(a)  No person shall operate a food establishment or engage in the business of processing, handling, or storing foods in the city for wholesale distribution or engage in the business of selling, handling, or delivering foods at retail, or operate any vending machine in the city without having first obtained a license therefor, issued in accordance with chapter 26. No such license shall be issued except upon certification of the health officer. 
(b)  License fees shall be as specified in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance. In addition an investigating fee as specified in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance shall be paid by each applicant, which fee shall be retained by the city regardless of whether any license is issued. A person wishing to operate a food stand for a period of not in excess of six continuous days shall not be required to pay the fees as provided for in this section and shall not be required to comply with the provisions of sections 58-36 and 58-38 through 58-45. License fees required under this section shall be waived as to any applicant who is subject to the payment of permit fees to the county under any county rules and regulations relating to food establishments. 
(c)  Only one license shall be issued under this section to each person for the operation of any food stand in any six-month period. 
(d)  No license required by this section shall be issued to any food establishment which will engage in the sale of prepared foods or beverages where the sale, delivery and/or consumption of such food takes place outside of the food establishment but on premises furnished for such purpose by the person operating the food establishment, unless a special use permit pursuant to section 126-347, allowing such activity, has been granted. 
(Code 1963, § 6.2; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 58-31. - Display of license. 
    It shall be the duty of any person licensed under this article to keep his license conspicuously displayed where it is readily observable by the public. When a business is conducted in a building, the license shall be hung conspicuously upon a wall or in some other conspicuous place in such building; when any person is operating a food establishment in a wagon, truck or other licensed vehicle, such licensee shall keep such license plate securely fastened to the vehicle so as to be readily visible at all times. 
(Code 1963, § 6.3) 
Sec. 58-32. - Suspension, revocation of licenses. 
    The suspension and revocation of licenses issued under this article shall be in accordance with chapter 26 as modified by the provisions of section 58-29. 
(Code 1963, § 6.4) 
Sec. 58-33. - Disease control. 
    No person who is affected with any disease in a communicable form or is a carrier of such disease shall work in any food establishment; and no food establishment shall employ any such person or any person suspected of being affected with any disease in a communicable form or of being a carrier of such disease. If the food establishment manager suspects that any employee has contracted any disease, he shall notify the health officer immediately. All employees shall have food handler's permits issued to them by the health officer. Such permits shall be kept on file at the food establishment. Such permits shall constitute certificates of health, renewable on each annual date of issuance. The issuance of such permits shall be based upon uniformly sufficient medical evidence which, in the opinion of the health officer, will insure insofar as is practicable, freedom from communicable disease or a carrier state. The health officer may make such other reasonable requirements for the issuance or renewal of such permits as he may deem necessary. 
(Code 1963, § 6.5) 
Sec. 58-34. - Procedure when infection suspected. 
    When suspicion arises as to the possibility of transmission of infection from any food establishment employee, the health officer is authorized to require any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  The immediate exclusion of the employee from all food establishments. 
(2)  The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned until no further danger of disease outbreak exists in the opinion of the health officer. 
(3)  Adequate medical examination of the employee and of his associates and such laboratory examinations as may be indicated. The employee shall assume the financial obligations, if any, required to perform these examinations. 
(Code 1963, § 6.6) 
Sec. 58-35. - Personal cleanliness required. 
    No person shall engage in any practice which is unsanitary or which tends to be detrimental to the cleanliness and sanitation of any food establishment or the health of the patrons thereof. While engaged in handling food, beverages, utensils or equipment, employees shall keep their persons clean and wear clean garments. Hands and fingernails of all employees coming in contact with food or utensils shall be clean. Employees shall wear hair coverings at all times while engaged in the preparation or handling of unwrapped or otherwise unprotected foods or beverages. No employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without first washing his hands with soap and warm water. No person shall expectorate in a food establishment. No person shall use tobacco in any form in any area in which food is prepared or act in any manner detrimental to the cleanliness and sanitation of the establishment. 
(Code 1963, § 6.7) 
Sec. 58-36. - Construction, reconstruction and alteration of establishments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remodel or alter any existing building or portion thereof which is being used or is proposed for use as a food establishment, or to construct a new building which is to be used in whole or in part as a food establishment without first having submitted plans thereof in duplicate to the health officer for approval. Such plans shall be accompanied by such other data as will completely describe the food establishment or the addition or alteration proposed. If approved, one set of plans bearing such approval in writing shall be returned to the applicant. If not approved, the manner in which such plans do not meet the requirements of this article shall be marked on both sets of plans, and one set of plans shall be returned to the applicant. 
(Code 1963, § 6.8) 
Sec. 58-37. - Condemnation of unfit foods. 
    Samples of food and beverages and other substances may be taken and examined by the health officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. It shall be the duty of the health officer to seize, condemn, or exclude from sale, delivery or distribution in the city any spoiled, contaminated or adulterated food or any food otherwise considered by the health officer as unfit for human consumption. It shall further be the duty of the health officer to destroy or denature all food condemned as being unfit for human consumption and issue a statement to the person in charge of such food establishment, stating the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1963, § 6.9) 
Sec. 58-38. - Toilet facilities. 
    Every food establishment, except duly licensed trucks or wagons, shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities conforming with this article and the laws of the state. All dressing rooms, toilets and lavatories shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, well lighted, ventilated to the outside atmosphere in good repair and free from flies and other insects. Toilet facilities shall be provided with self-closing, tightfitted doors. Floors and walls shall be constructed of impervious material. 
(Code 1963, § 6.10) 
Sec. 58-39. - Lavatory requirements. 
    Handwashing facilities shall be provided in all food establishments, except duly licensed trucks or wagons. Handwashing facilities shall be adequate and convenient to the toilet rooms and to areas where food is prepared. Hot and cold running water, soap and approved individual sanitary towels shall be provided at all lavatories. Sinks used for utensil washing or food preparation shall not be used for handwashing. Handwashing sinks shall not be used for washing utensils or food preparation. Handwashing facilities shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
(Code 1963, § 6.11) 
Sec. 58-40. - Water requirements. 
    Only municipal water shall be used by licensees under this article. Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible in all areas in which food is prepared or utensils are washed. The water supply shall be ample in quantity to make possible the cleaning of walls, floors and utensils. Each sink shall have hot and cold running water under pressure at all times. 
(Code 1963, § 6.12) 
Sec. 58-41. - Floors. 
    The floors of all rooms used by licensees under this article shall be smooth and of such construction as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
(Code 1963, § 6.13) 
Sec. 58-42. - Walls and ceilings. 
    Walls and ceilings of all rooms used by licensees under this article shall be kept clean and in good repair. All walls and ceilings of rooms in which food or beverages are prepared shall be finished in light color. The walls of all rooms in which food or beverages are prepared or utensils are washed shall have smooth, washable surfaces and shall be kept in clean condition. 
(Code 1963, § 6.14) 
Sec. 58-43. - Doors and windows. 
    All doors, windows and screens on premises used by licensees under this article shall be kept clean and in good repair. When flies are prevalent all openings into the outer air shall be effectively screened and doors shall be self-closing, unless other effective means are provided to prevent the entrance of flies. The use of electrical devices for the dispensing of vapors of toxic insecticides, on a continuous basis, shall not be allowed. 
(Code 1963, § 6.15) 
Sec. 58-44. - Ventilation. 
    All rooms in which food or beverages are stored, prepared or served, or in which utensils are washed, shall be well ventilated. A properly designed metal hood shall be suspended and extended over all cooking equipment at a convenient height and properly connected with an exhaust fan or a blower and ventilating flue sufficient to carry cooking odors and vapors to the outside atmosphere. All hoods installed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall be equipped with removable grease filters. 
(Code 1963, § 6.16) 
Sec. 58-45. - Lighting. 
    Natural or artificial light equivalent to a minimum of 30 footcandles shall be provided on all working surfaces in rooms in which food is prepared, in which utensils are washed, and at serving stations. 
(Code 1963, § 6.17) 
Sec. 58-46. - Utensils and equipment. 
    All multiuse utensils used in connection with the operation of a food establishment shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair. All equipment installed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived for use in the cleansing, processing, bactericidal treatment, preparation, storing, handling or serving of food or drink for consumers shall meet the National Sanitation Foundation Standards. 
(Code 1963, § 6.18) 
Sec. 58-47. - Cleaning and bactericidal treatment of utensils and equipment. 
(a)  All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves, hoods, and sinks, in a food establishment shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects, and other contaminating material. All cloths used by waiters, chefs, and other employees shall be clean. Single-service containers shall be used only once. All multiuse eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal process after each usage. All multiuse utensils used in the preparation of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively rinsed immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and shall be used for no other purpose. No article, polish or other substances containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous materials shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils. 
(b)  The health officer is hereby empowered to adopt detailed rules and regulations in order to effectuate the provisions of this section. Such rules and regulations shall be effective upon the filing of copies of same with the city clerk. No person shall fail to comply with any provisions of such rules and regulations. 
(Code 1963, § 6.19) 
Sec. 58-48. - Storing of utensils. 
    After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected from flies, dust, and other contamination and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent contamination as far as practicable. Single service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers, shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place until used and shall be handled in a sanitary manner. Only single service utensils which have been manufactured, packaged, stored and transported under sanitary conditions shall be used. Utensils such as spoons, spatulas, dipper and scoops used for dispensing frozen desserts when not in use shall be kept in running water. 
(Code 1963, § 6.20) 
Sec. 58-49. - Disposal of wastes. 
    All wastes, garbage and rubbish shall be properly disposed of in compliance with this Code. All garbage and rubbish shall be kept in suitable receptacles in such a manner as not to become a nuisance, such receptacles shall be approved by the health officer or his appropriate employee. All plumbing shall be so designed, installed and maintained as to prevent contamination of the water supply, food, beverages or equipment. 
(Code 1963, § 6.21) 
Sec. 58-50. - Refrigeration. 
    All perishable food and drink shall be kept at or below 40 degrees Fahrenheit, except when being prepared or served. Wastewater from refrigeration equipment shall be properly disposed of. 
(Code 1963, § 6.22) 
Sec. 58-51. - Food must be clean and wholesome. 
    All food and beverages shall be clean and wholesome, free from spoilage and so prepared as to be safe for human consumption. All milk and milk products shall be from approved sources and shall have been pasteurized. Milk and milk products shall be served in the individual original containers in which they were received from the distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an approved dispensing device, provided that cream may be served in containers or from dispensers approved by the health officer. All oysters, clams, and mussels shall be from approved sources and if shucked shall be kept until used in the containers in which they were placed at the shucking plant. 
(Code 1963, § 6.23) 
Sec. 58-52. - Protection from contamination. 
(a)  All food and beverages shall be prepared, stored, displayed and served so as to be protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet infection, overhead leakage and other forms of contamination. No animals or fowl shall be kept or allowed in any room in which food or drink is prepared, stored or served. All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches, other insects and rodents in an approved manner shall be used. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions, this section is not intended to prohibit the operation of seasonal outdoor cafes when operated in conjunction with an established indoor restaurant. 
(Code 1963, § 6.24) 
Sec. 58-53. - Premises must be clean. 
    The premises of all food establishments shall be kept clean and free of litter or rubbish. None of the operations connected with the food establishment shall be conducted in any room used as living or sleeping quarters. Where a food establishment is located in the same building as the living quarters, there shall be no direct opening between the two. Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees' clothing and shall be kept clean. Soiled linens, coats, and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for this purpose. 
(Code 1963, § 6.25) 
Sec. 58-54. - Food to be kept in enclosed building. 
    It shall be unlawful to store or expose for sale in open receptacles or broken packages, vegetables, fruits and farm produce unless the same shall be kept not less than 18 inches above the floor. All foods stored in the city for ultimate sale except by licensed peddlers under chapter 26 shall be kept within an enclosed building which complies with the provisions of the building code of the city and which has been approved by the health officer or his authorized representative. 
(Code 1963, § 6.26) 
Sec. 58-55. - Milk delivery vehicles. 
(a)  Persons engaged in the business of delivering milk within the city shall not be required to obtain the license required by this article. Such persons shall obtain a milk delivery license issued in accordance with chapter 26 of this Code. 
(b)  Every vehicle used for the delivery of milk shall be constructed with a permanent top and with permanent or movable sides and back, provided that openings of a size necessary for the delivery man to pass through may be permitted in the sides or back for loading and unloading purposes. 
(c)  Vehicles shall be kept clean and no substance capable of contaminating pasteurized milk or milk products shall be transported. 
(d)  Vehicles used for the delivery of milk shall have the name of the licensed milk plant prominently displayed on each outer side. 
(e)  Any vehicle used in the delivery of milk shall provide some method of refrigerating milk and milk products at temperatures of not to exceed 40 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Code 1963, § 6.27) 
Secs. 58-56-58-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PRIVATE WATER WELLS 

Sec. 58-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private well means any well or excavation for purposes of taking artesian water, drilled or dug on any privately owned lands to a depth of more than 12 feet. 
(Code 1963, § 2.91) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-77. - Purpose. 
(a)  The regulation of private wells is intended to prevent waste, in an unreasonable manner, of water from artesian wells, or the use thereof which may in any way cause depletion or lowering of the head or reservoir thereof to the detriment or damage of other wells in the city. 
(b)  Any private well dug, drilled or operated and maintained in violation of any provision of this article or of the permit for such well, shall be a public nuisance, and the same shall be abated forthwith. 
(Code 1963, § 2.101) 
Sec. 58-78. - Permit required. 
    No person shall dig or drill a private well upon any lands within the city without having first secured a permit therefor from the city commission, nor shall any private well be extended or enlarged without having first secured a permit under this article. 
(Code 1963, § 2.92) 
Sec. 58-79. - Application fee. 
    Any person desiring to dig, drill, extend or enlarge any private well shall make application therefor to the city commission. Such application shall be in writing and shall contain all pertinent information concerning the size and location of the proposed well or extension thereof with a statement of the purpose for which water therefrom will be used. Such application shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance which fee shall be returned if the permit is not granted. 
(Code 1963, § 2.93; Ord. No. 1507, § 2.93, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 58-80. - Hearing. 
    The city commission shall hold a hearing on an application for a permit under this article as it may deem necessary, and may grant or deny issuance of a permit. If a permit is granted, the same shall contain such reasonable terms and conditions as the commission may deem necessary, relative to the depth or size of such private well, and the use and disposal of water taken therefrom. 
(Code 1963, § 2.94) 
Sec. 58-81. - Regulations. 
    When any permit is granted for the drilling of any private well, such well shall be drilled in strict conformity and compliance with regulations contained in such permit and such well, both at the time of drilling and subsequent thereto, shall be subject to inspection at all reasonable times by the water department of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 2.95) 
Sec. 58-82. - Meter. 
    The city commission may, as a condition precedent to the granting of any permit under this article, require installation on any private well of a meter measuring the amount of water taken therefrom. Such meter if so required shall be installed by the water department of the city. All costs in connection therewith shall be borne by the owner of such premises and shall be an additional charge over and above the required permit fee. 
(Code 1963, § 2.96) 
Sec. 58-83. - Disposition of waste. 
    No water from private wells within the city shall be permitted to enter the sewer system of the city unless the same first passes through a meter duly installed and approved by the city water department. 
(Code 1963, § 2.97) 
Sec. 58-84. - Sewer charges. 
    Water from private wells deposited in the sewer system of the city shall be subject to the same charges as are provided for sewage treatment of water from the city water system. 
(Code 1963, § 2.98) 
Sec. 58-85. - Revocation of permit. 
    Any permit granted under this article shall be revocable at the will of the city commission. The commission, prior to revoking such permit, shall give to the owner or operator of such well at least 90 days' written notice of its intent to revoke such permit. Such notice shall be deemed sufficient if served on such owner personally, or by registered or regular mail and by posting a copy thereof on the premises where such well is located. Use of water shall be discontinued forthwith on revocation of such permit. Such well shall be capped or otherwise treated as required by order of the commission. 
(Code 1963, § 2.99) 
Sec. 58-86. - Water sales. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell water from any private well, except by express permission of the city commission, or to use water for any purpose or purposes other than those specified in the permit granted therefor. 
(Code 1963, § 2.100) 
Secs. 58-87-58-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DAY CARE HOMES AND CHILD CARE CENTERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1797, adopted January 27, 2003, amended art. IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, art. IV pertained to day care nurseries and derived from Code 1963, § § 6.51-6.63. 

Sec. 58-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Child care center means a facility, other than a private residence, where child care is provided for periods of fewer than 24 hours a day, for more than two consecutive weeks per year, for one or more children whose parents/guardians are not immediately available. Child care centers include public or private preschools, nursery schools, parent cooperative preschools, full-day child care centers and crop in centers and must be licensed by the state. 
    Day care home, family means a dwelling in which a permanent occupant of the dwelling provides for the care of fewer than seven minor children unrelated to the care provider for periods of fewer than 24 hours a day, for more than four weeks in a calendar year unattended by the children's parents or legal guardians, and must be licensed and/or registered by the state. 
    Day care home, group means a dwelling in which a permanent occupant of the dwelling provides for the care of fewer than thirteen minor children unrelated to the care provider for periods of fewer than 24 hours a day, for more than four weeks in a calendar year, unattended by the children's parents or legal guardians, and must be licensed and/or registered by the state. 
    Food means any article intended for human consumption, and all beverages and liquids except water. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2; businesses, ch. 26. 
Sec. 58-107. - Purpose. 
    It shall be the scope and purpose of this article to provide for the safety, protection of the health, well being and general welfare of children received for day care and nursing in child care centers, family day care homes and group day care homes. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-108. - Regulations-Authorized. 
    The health officer and the fire chief are hereby empowered to make such regulations and amend same as are necessary to carry out the scope and purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-109. - Same-When effective. 
    Regulations adopted pursuant to this article shall be effective when copies thereof signed by the health officer and the fire chief, as the case may be, are filed with the city clerk. Such regulations shall be public records and may be examined at the office of the city clerk at any time such office is open for business. Such regulations shall not be effective longer than 30 days after such filing, unless the same be approved by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-110. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of operating, or shall operate a child care center, family day care home or a group day care home in the city without having first procured a license. Any person to whom such a license has been issued shall at all times operate such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home strictly in accordance with the provisions of such license. No such license shall be issued except upon certification of the health officer and fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-111. - Application for license; investigations. 
(a)  Any person desiring to procure a license for the operation of a child care center, family day care home or a group day care home shall file with the health officer an application on such form as he shall provide, giving such information as shall be required by the health officer, and in addition shall execute an agreement that he will operate such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home, if the license is issued, in strict accordance with regulations promulgated under this article. 
(b)  Such application shall be accompanied by the required fee to cover the cost of the investigation to determine whether such license should be issued. Such investigation fee shall be in addition to the required license fee and shall not be returnable. Such investigation fee shall not be again charged upon renewal of any license under this article unless the conditions under which the child care center, family day care home or a group day care home is to be operated shall have been changed so as to again require an investigation. 
(c)  The health officer or his agent shall forthwith proceed to examine the premises wherein it is proposed to operate such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home, and shall ascertain whether the applicant and any other person to be employed in such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home are proper persons to engage in such business. If he shall determine that such person is a proper person and that the accommodations on the premises comply in all regards with the provisions of this article, and with all regulations made by him for such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home and with such other regulations, he shall endorse his approval on such application, stating therein the maximum number of children who may be received in such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home at any one time, the lower and upper age limits of such children and the hours during which the child care center, family day care home or a group day care home may be open, and during which children may be received. He shall then deliver such application to the fire chief, who shall examine premises to determine whether the same complies with the laws and regulations then in force. If he shall find that such premises do comply with all laws, provisions of this Code and such regulations, he shall endorse his approval on such application and the same shall be delivered to the city clerk. If requested by either the health officer or the fire chief, the premises shall also be inspected by the building official to ascertain whether or not the same be structurally sound, and he shall report his findings to the health officer. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-112. - Issuance of license. 
    Upon receipt of the application bearing the approval of the health officer and the fire chief endorsed thereon, and upon payment of the required license fee, the city clerk shall issue to the applicant a license for the operation of such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home, which license shall state the maximum number of children permitted to be received in such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home at any one time, the lower and upper age limits of such children, the hours during which such children may be received, and the name of the operator and the permitted employees, and the room and/or area in which the child care center, family day care home or a group day care home may be operated. Any change in such employees shall be reported to the health officer forthwith, for examination of any employee as may be required. The continued employment of a person found by the health officer not to be a proper person for such employment may be grounds for a revocation of the license in accordance with chapter 26. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-113. - Inspection, closure. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer and of the fire chief to provide for the periodic inspection of all such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home licensed under this article. If it shall be determined from such inspection that such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home is not complying with the provisions of this article, or of regulations of the health officer and of the fire chief, the health officer shall immediately order such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home closed, and any such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home so closed shall not reopen until there has been issued a certificate by the health officer and the fire chief that the conditions bringing about such closing order have been corrected. The licensee shall have the right to appeal to the city commission from such closing by the health officer. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-114. - Serving of food. 
    If it shall appear from the application filed for a license under this article that the applicant proposes to serve food in the child care center, family day care home or a group day care home all persons preparing or serving such food shall be required to procure a food handler's card from the health officer, which card shall be in addition to the license required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-115. - Disease control. 
    no parent or guardian shall knowingly bring or send to such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home any child who is afflicted with any communicable disease. No parent or guardian shall give any false or misleading information concerning the health of their children. It shall be the duty of the child care center, family day care home or a group day care home to require the parents or guardians to remove any child coming under this section from such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-116. - Registry of children. 
    Each child care center, family day care home or a group day care home shall keep a perpetual register of all children received therein, which shall show in addition to the name and home address of such child, his age and sex, the time such child is received, and the time when released from the child care center, family day care home or a group day care home, and shall record the name of the family physician of each child, or of some physician authorized by the parent or guardian to be called in case of an emergency requiring the services of a physician. Such register shall at all times be kept near the main entrance of the day child care center, family day care home or a group day care home in such a place as to be readily accessible and out of reach of the children. No person shall tamper with such register, or alter, deface or remove pages from the same. The register shall at all times be open to inspection by the health officer, and the fire chief and to members of the police department, and shall be delivered to any of such persons upon request; provided, however, that the same shall not be removed from such child care center, family day care home or a group day care home during the hours it is in operation. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-117. - Display of license. 
    All licenses issued under this article, together with copies of regulations of the health officer and of the fire chief shall at all times when such day child care center, family day care home or a group day care home is in operation be posted in a conspicuous place therein, and shall be available for examination by any official of the city, and by any parent or guardian bringing a child to such day child care center, family day care home or a group day care home. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-118. - Rooms or areas used. 
    No child care center, family day care home or a group day care home shall be conducted in any room or area used for any other purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03) 
Sec. 58-119. - Other group day care home regulations. 
    Group day care homes are also subject to all other applicable city ordinances, including, but not limited to, subsection 126-421(4)(d), chapter 26, and the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 58-120. - Other family day care home regulations. 
    Family day care homes are also subject to all other applicable city ordinances, including, but not limited to, subsection 126-97(8), chapter 26, and the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 58-121. - Child care center regulations. 
    Child care centers are also subject to all other applicable city ordinances, including, but not limited to, subsection 126.324(3), subsection 126-326(2) and the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance. 
(Ord. No. 1797, 1-27-03; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Secs. 58-122-58-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FUMIGATORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26. 

Sec. 58-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fumigation means the process of fumigating or exterminating insects, vermin, rodents or other pests, including germs, in which process is used hydrocyanic acid gas, or other poisonous, noxious or dangerous gases, fumes or vapors, specified by the health officer as liable to affect human beings by causing severe sickness or death. 
    Fumigator means one competently trained and experienced in the use of fumigants. He must understand the hazards involved, precautionary and safety measures, use of gas masks, effect, residual and otherwise, upon foods and commodities, dosages and exposure periods necessary, and provisions for adequate ventilation and safe reoccupancy. 
(Code 1963, § 6.71) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-142. - Licenses. 
    No person shall engage in the business of fumigation or in the occupation of fumigator without first obtaining a license therefor. No such license shall be granted except upon the certification of the fire chief that the applicant has been examined and found qualified. 
(Code 1963, § 6.72) 
Sec. 58-143. - Fumigant contractor license. 
    A license issued under this article to engage in the business of fumigation, shall be known as a fumigant contractor license. When an applicant for a fumigant contractor license shall be a partnership or corporation, there must be at all times, during the term of such license, a member of the partnership, and an officer of the corporation, respectively, who is qualified as a fumigant contractor. 
(Code 1963, § 6.73) 
Sec. 58-144. - Insurance. 
    Before any fumigant contractor license is issued, the applicant therefor shall furnish one or more policies of insurance as set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds, and insurance. 
(Code 1963, § 6.74; Ord. No. 2013, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 58-145. - Regulations. 
    After obtaining a license under this article, the licensee shall be permitted to engage in the operation of exterminating household pests and/or fumigating in buildings by means of the methods designated in such license; provided he complies with the following provisions: 
(1)  For each such separate operation, he shall take out a permit, the application for which shall show the number and the date of expiration of the licensee's license, the location of the building in which such operation is proposed, the date and hour of commencing such operation and the type of exterminating or fumigating agent to be used. The cost of such permit shall be $1.00. Applications for such permit shall be made to the fire chief or to an employee duly designated by him. It shall be the duty of the fire chief or employee to issue such permit, collect the cost thereof and see that the payment received is properly turned over to the city treasurer. It shall also be the duty of the fire chief to see that all premises undergoing such operations are inspected during such operations to the end that the provisions of this article are complied with. 
(2)  Before exposure of the space in which the extermination of pests and/or fumigation is to be conducted, to the exterminating or fumigating agent, the licensee shall be required to do the following things: 
a.  See that all persons, domestic animals and things that are intended for human consumption, unless such things are hermetically sealed, are removed from such space. 
b.  Seal all openings into such space through which such agent might escape. 
c.  Securely lock all openings into such space through which persons might enter such space and post prominently a substantial red placard, not less than eight inches by ten inches in size, reading "Danger-Do Not Enter" in large type at each opening. 
(Code 1963, § 6.75) 
Sec. 58-146. - Explosive fumigants. 
    When hydrocyanic acid gas, cyanogen chloride or combinations thereof, one with the other, or with other gases or when any explosive gases are used for extermination and/or fumigation purposes, the following precautions shall be observed: 
(1)  All fires within such space shall be extinguished. 
(2)  For containing the ingredients necessary in the preparation of such gases, the container used shall be fire resistant and inert to chemical reaction with such ingredients and gases. 
(3)  Great care shall be taken to prevent cyanide crystals or other substances injurious to human beings being spilled or left exposed where persons may come in contact with them. 
(4)  The residue left in such containers, after completion of the operation of extermination and/or fumigation shall be disposed of by dumping into and thoroughly flushing into the sewer system. 
(Code 1963, § 6.76) 
Sec. 58-147. - Patrol. 
    Throughout the time during which any space is being exposed to the exterminating or fumigating agent, the conditions outlined in sections 58-145(2) and 58-146(1), (2) and (3) shall be strictly maintained. In addition thereto, a guard shall be placed on the premises who shall constantly patrol outside of such space to prevent the entrance of any person or domestic animal. 
(Code 1963, § 6.77) 
Sec. 58-148. - Ventilation and inspection. 
    Upon completion of the exterminating and/or fumigating operation, the licensee or his agents shall open such openings into any fumigated space as may be necessary to thoroughly ventilate such space and remove all traces of the exterminating and/or fumigating agent. During such ventilating operation, sufficient guards shall be maintained around the space to prevent and they shall prevent the entrance of any person except the licensee or his agent, or any domestic animal into such space until the licensee or his agent, while unprotected by any gas mask or other device for protection from injurious gases or substances, shall have entered and thoroughly inspected every room or enclosed area within such space and shall have determined all of such space to be free from injurious gases and/or other injurious substances. 
(Code 1963, § 6.78) 
Sec. 58-149. - Protection of public. 
    The licensee under this article shall do any and all things necessary to the end that the public shall receive the maximum protection at all times in connection with the operation hereinbefore described. 
(Code 1963, § 6.79) 
Chapter 62 - HISTORICAL PRESERVATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; zoning, ch. 126. 
State Law reference- Historical activities, MCL 399.171 et seq.; historic districts, MCL 399.201 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 62-1-62-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUSEUM BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005, adopted January 25, 2010, amended article II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article II pertained to the historical board, and derived from the Code of 1963, §§ 1.201-1.210, and Ord. No. 1719, adopted December 20, 1999. 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-171 et seq. 

Sec. 62-26. - Establishment; composition. 
    There is hereby established the museum board for the city which shall consist of seven members who shall serve without compensation. Six of the members shall be appointed by the city commission and shall be qualified city electors. One member shall be the owner of a business located in the city to be appointed by the city manager with the concurrence of the city commission (need not be a resident). A majority of the members of the museum board shall also be members of the Birmingham Historical Society. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 62-27. - Terms of members. 
    Each member shall be appointed for a term of three years ending on the first Monday of July of the third year after appointment, or upon the appointment of his successor, whichever is later, except that in the first instance three of the members shall be appointed for a one-year term and two shall be appointed for two-year terms. Members of the museum board shall hold office at the pleasure of the city commission. Vacancies occurring other than through the expiration of term shall be filled for the unexpired term by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 62-28. - Organization. 
    The museum board shall elect a chairman from its membership annually at its first meeting after the first Monday of July. The city clerk shall be a nonvoting ex officio member of the museum board and shall serve as its secretary; and the city treasurer shall be a nonvoting ex officio member of the museum board and shall serve as its treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 62-29. - Meetings. 
    The museum board shall hold at least one regular public meeting in each quarter on such date and at such time and place as may be established by resolution of the museum board. Special meetings may be called by the secretary on the written request of the chairman or any three members of the museum board on at least two days' notice. The museum board shall adopt such rules for the conduct of its business as it may from time to time adopt by resolution. The museum board shall keep a written or printed record of its proceedings which shall be a public record and property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 62-30. - Expenditures. 
    The museum board shall have the power to expend such funds as may from time to time be appropriated to it by the city commission or otherwise received by it for the purpose of carrying out the powers and duties of the museum board. An account of all its receipts and expenditures shall be maintained which shall be a public record and property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 62-31. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  Mission statement. The Birmingham Museum will explore meaningful connections with our past, in order to enrich our community and enhance its character and sustainability. Our mission is to promote understanding of Birmingham's historical and cultural legacy through preservation and interpretation of its ongoing story. 
(b)  In general, it shall be the duty of the museum board to: 
(1)  Collect, arrange, catalogue and preserve historical material including books, pamphlets, maps, charts, manuscripts, papers, records and archives, paintings, statuary and other objects and materials relating to the history of the city and the surrounding area; 
(2)  Procure and preserve narratives of the residents of such area; 
(3)  Collect material of every description relative to the history, and culture of our Oakland County Native American tribes; 
(4)  Collect, prepare and display objects indicative of the life, customs, dress and resources of the residents of this area; and 
(5)  Make available from time to time source materials and historical studies relative to and illustrative of the history of the area. 
(c)  The museum board shall have the power, with the assistance of all city public officials, to collect from the public offices in the city reproductions of any records, files, documents, books and papers which, in the opinion of the museum board are of historical value. 
(d)  The museum board shall have the power to develop, operate and maintain the 1928 Allen House, 1822 John West Hunter House and John West Hunter Memorial Park, as part of the Birmingham Museum, as a museum and to serve as an advisory authority exercising control and management over this cultural resource. 
(e)  The museum board shall have the power to raise funds for the exercise of its powers and duties. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10; Ord. No. 2176, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 62-32. - Executive director. 
    There shall be an executive director who shall be an employee of the city. The executive director shall, among other duties as established by the museum board, operate and manage the museum. The executive director shall report to the museum board and shall be appointed, removed and supervised by the city manager. The executive director shall attend all meetings of the museum board. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 62-33. - Reports. 
    The museum board shall make and submit to the city commission annually a report of the general activities, operation, and condition of the Birmingham Museum for the preceding 12 months. The museum board shall, from time to time, as occasion requires, either in the annual report, or at any time deemed necessary by the museum board, advise the city commission in writing on all matters necessary and proper for and pertaining to the proper operation of the Birmingham Museum and any of its activities or properties. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10; Ord. No. 2176, 3-14-16) 
Sec. 62-34. - Budget. 
    The executive director, on behalf of the museum board, will submit a complete itemized budget for the ensuing fiscal year to the city manager based on guidelines established in the city budgetary process. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 62-35. - Protection of property. 
    No person shall take, use, or occupy any property under the control of the museum board except in accordance with such rules and regulations governing such as may from time to time be prescribed by the museum board. 
(Ord. No. 2005, 1-25-10) 
Secs. 62-36-62-55. - Reserved.

Chapter 66 - HUMAN RELATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
