Sec. 110-166. - Commercial vehicles. 
    No commercial vehicle, except one commercial vehicle of not more than three-quarters-ton capacity, shall be parked on any land, located within zone districts R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5, R-6, R-7 and R-8 as set forth in chapter 126 between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m.; however, this prohibition shall not be applicable to vehicles being parked or stored for the sole purpose of rendering an immediate and current service to a building located on the premises upon which such vehicle is parked. 
(Code 1963, § 5.506) 
Sec. 110-167. - Modified house trailers in B-2 or B-4 zone districts. 
(a)  A house trailer modified so as to be used for nonresidential purposes may, when issued a permit by the city commission, be parked in a B-2 or B-4 zone district. The city commission shall issue a permit good for a one-year period when satisfied that the applicant has met the following conditions: 
(1)  That the sole purpose of parking or storing the modified house trailer shall be to provide medical or health service, which is available to the general public, without charge and is provided by a nonprofit organization. 
(2)  That the trailer for which a permit is sought conforms to all state regulations and is licensed for highway travel. 
(3)  That water supply and sewage disposal storage tanks are provided in the trailer. 
(4)  That the trailer contains at least two exits, remote enough from each other to provide alternate routes of egress, and also contains an approved portable fire extinguisher. 
(5)  That all electrical and heating equipment is of a type that the building inspector determines does not constitute a hazard to the safety of the trailer or its occupants. 
(b)  Any trailer parked or stored pursuant to a permit issued by the city commission under this section shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  No modified house trailer shall be used for cooking, eating, sleeping or other residential purposes. 
(2)  The number of people occupying a modified house trailer, shall not exceed the limit established by the fire department, and the owner shall conspicuously post such limit. 
(3)  No freestanding oil or propane tanks shall be located on the site. 
(4)  Any trailer issued a permit under this section shall be removed from the premises at least six days in each six-month period. 
(5)  The city commission may authorize direct connections to sewer and water utilities if the lack of the facilities would seriously hamper the efficiency of the operation and therefore, the resultant public benefit. 
(Code 1963, § 5.507) 
Secs. 110-168-110-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRANSPORTATION REGULATORY REQUESTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Prior to the reenactment of article VII by Ord. No. 2139, adopted February 10, 2014, Ord. No. 1995, adopted September 21, 2009, repealed the former article VII, divisions 1 and 2, in its entirety, which pertained to bicycles and derived from the Code of 1963, §§ 10.41-10.44. 

Sec. 110-191. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to maintain the effective functioning of the city's transportation system for all users, of all ages and abilities. 
(Ord. No. 2139, 2-10-14) 
Sec. 110-192. - Review. 
    Applications for all transportation related regulatory requests, including but not limited to, regulatory signs, signals, markings and devices, and the regulation of commercial and residential parking, shall be submitted to the police department for administrative review. 
(Ord. No. 2139, 2-10-14) 
Sec. 110-193. - Application. 
    Each transportation related regulatory request submitted to the police department under this article shall be on such forms and contain such information as the police department shall determine necessary, including but not limited to an explanation of the request, the reason(s) for the request, and a basic site plan of the conditions of the area in question. 
(Ord. No. 2139, 2-10-14) 
Sec. 110-194. - Application fee. 
    An application fee as established by the city commission shall be payable upon submitting an application for a transportation related request. 
(Ord. No. 2139, 2-10-14) 
Sec. 110-195. - Decision on request. 
    After reviewing the transportation related regulatory request, the police department may approve the request, approve on a trial basis for a limited period of time, or deny the request. 
(Ord. No. 2139, 2-10-14) 
Sec. 110-196. - Appeal. 
    Any applicant for administrative review under this article aggrieved by a decision of the police department shall have the right to appeal the decision to the multi-modal transportation board. 
(Ord. No. 2139, 2-10-14) 
Secs. 110-197-110-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CIVIL REIMBURSEMENT 

Sec. 110-226. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings described in this section unless the context specifically indicates a different meaning: 
    Costs and expenses of emergency response means reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the city making an emergency response, including, but not limited to, the actual costs and expenses of the hourly wage of firefighting, police and emergency medical service personnel, including overtime wages, costs and expenses for special equipment used during the response, and the costs and expenses of any special personnel and/or companies or organizations called to the scene to assist in the response, but such costs and expenses shall only include those costs and expenses directly arising because of the response to the particular incident. Such costs shall include the cost of any type of chemical testing for blood alcohol content or for the presence of controlled substances and for videotaping of driver, if applicable. If legal action is instituted to collect the costs and expenses of emergency response under this article, all legal fees and costs incurred by the city in such legal action shall also be included in the costs and expenses of such emergency response. 
    Emergency response means: 
(1)  The providing, sending and/or utilizing of public service, police, firefighting and/or rescue services by the city at an accident involving a motor vehicle or vehicles, where one or more of the drivers of such vehicle or vehicles were operating the motor vehicle while under the influence; or 
(2)  The making of a traffic stop and arrest by a police officer when the driver was operating the motor vehicle while under the influence. 
    Operating under the influence means the operation of a motor vehicle [while] under the influence of intoxicating liquor and/or controlled substances or while visibly impaired by intoxicating liquor and/or controlled substances or with an unlawful blood alcohol content by weight of alcohol, regardless of whether such person is charged or convicted of any crime relating to the incident causing the emergency response. For purposes of this article, it shall be presumed that a person was operating a motor vehicle under the influence if chemical analysis of the driver's blood, urine, or breath indicates the presence of any amount of a controlled substance or that the amount of alcohol in the driver's blood was in excess of 0.07 percent. 
(Ord. No. 1588, 5-16-94) 
Sec. 110-227. - Liability for expenses. 
    Any person who, while under the influence, operates a motor vehicle which operation results in an emergency response shall be responsible and/or liable for the expenses of the emergency response. 
(Ord. No. 1588, 5-16-94) 
Sec. 110-228. - Civil liability. 
    This article shall be construed to impose a responsibility and liability of a civil nature on the part of the operator of the motor vehicle and shall not be construed to conflict, contravene, enlarge or reduce any criminal liability or responsibility, including fines and costs which may be imposed by a judge on an operator of a motor vehicle convicted of any criminal action arising from the incident precipitating the emergency response. 
(Ord. No. 1588, 5-16-94) 
Sec. 110-229. - Collection of debt. 
    All costs and expenses incurred under this article shall be collectable by the city in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under a contract, express or implied. 
(Ord. No. 1588, 5-16-94) 
Sec. 110-230. - City treasurer to submit bill. 
    As soon as practicable after receiving itemized costs and expenses incurred for an emergency response, the city treasurer shall submit a bill for those costs and expenses by first class mail or personal service to the person liable for the expenses, as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1588, 5-16-94) 
Sec. 110-231. - Payment of costs; failure to pay; recovery of costs by city attorney. 
    A person liable for the costs and expenses of an emergency response shall pay the bill submitted by the city treasurer as set forth above, within 30 days of receipt. If payment is not received by the city within such 30-day period, the city manager may instruct the city attorney to institute civil action on behalf of the city to recover the costs and expenses of the response and court costs and attorney fees incurred in the collection of such debt. 
(Ord. No. 1588, 5-16-94) 
Secs. 110-232-110-249. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - TRAFFIC ENGINEER AND TRAFFIC CONTROL ORDERS 

Sec. 110-250. - Traffic engineer. 
    The office of the traffic engineer is hereby established. The traffic engineer shall be appointed in a manner prescribed by the city commission and shall exercise the powers and duties provided in this Code in a manner which is consistent with prevailing traffic engineering and safety practices and which is in the best interests of the city. If a traffic engineer is not appointed, the authority of such engineer shall be vested in the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1782, § 1, 4-29-02) 
Sec. 110-251. - Duties of traffic engineer. 
    The general duties of the traffic engineer are as follows: 
(1)  To plan and determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control devices. 
(2)  To conduct engineering analysis of traffic accidents and devise remedial measures. 
(3)  To conduct engineering investigations to traffic conditions. 
(4)  To plan the operation of traffic on the streets of this city, including parking areas. 
(5)  To cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions. 
(6)  To carry out the additional powers and the duties imposed by the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 1782, § 1, 4-29-02) 
Sec. 110-252. - Traffic control orders. 
    The city commission, through the recommendation and investigation of the traffic safety board and/or the traffic engineer, may order traffic signs, signals, markings, and devices throughout the city in the interest of public safety and convenience and for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic as it deems appropriate. The traffic control order shall establish the location of the traffic control signs, signals, markings and/or devices and shall direct the city police department to carry out the order accordingly. The traffic control order shall be effective upon filing of the traffic control order with the city clerk and upon the erection of the appropriate signs, signals, markings and/or devices. A certified copy of the traffic control order shall be filed with the city clerk and with the clerk of Oakland County. 
(Ord. No. 1782, § 1, 4-29-02) 
Sec. 110-253. - Temporary traffic control orders. 
    Traffic control orders may be issued by the traffic engineer on his or her own authority, but when so issued shall be known as temporary traffic control orders. A temporary traffic control order shall set forth the location and a description of the signs, signals, markings and/or devices to be erected at that location and shall be ordered in the interest of public safety and convenience and for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. The temporary traffic control order shall be effective upon its filing with the city clerk and upon erection of the appropriate signs, signals, markings and/or devices and shall be valid for a period of time not to exceed 90 days, unless the temporary traffic control order is made a permanent traffic control order by the city commission. Upon the issuance of a temporary traffic control order, the traffic engineer may have the temporary traffic control order presented to the city commission for permanent traffic control consideration. Should the city commission approve the temporary traffic control order to be a permanent traffic control order, a certified copy of the traffic control order shall be filed with the city clerk and with the clerk of Oakland County. 
(Ord. No. 1782, § 1, 4-29-02) 
Sec. 110-254. - Traffic control order book. 
    All traffic control orders and temporary traffic control orders, and any action which modifies or repeals such orders, shall be kept by the city clerk in a separate book which shall be known as the traffic control order book. 
(Ord. No. 1782, § 1, 4-29-02) 
Sec. 110-255. - Use of traffic control orders. 
    A copy of a traffic control order or temporary traffic control order, certified by the clerk to be a true copy compared by him or her with the original in his or her office, shall be permitted into evidence in all courts and proceedings in the same manner as the original would be permitted into evidence if produced. If it appears that a traffic control sign, signal, marking or device that conforms to the provisions of the City Code was erected or in place when the alleged violation of the City Code occurred, such showing shall be prima facie evidence of the existence of a lawful traffic control order or temporary traffic control order which authorizes such traffic control sign, signal, marking or device, and it is not necessary for the prosecution to affirmatively show the existence of a valid control order or temporary traffic control order in such case, unless and until such presumption is rebutted by competent evidence. 
(Ord. No. 1782, § 1, 4-29-02) 
Secs. 110-256-110-274. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PEDICABS AND COMMERCIAL QUADRICYCLES 

Sec. 110-275. - Purpose. 
    The transportation of persons by means of pedicabs or commercial quadricycles is a matter closely affecting the public interest. The public interest requires that pedicab and commercial quadricycle drivers be properly qualified persons, that the pedicabs and commercial quadricycles be fit for their intended purpose, and that the safety and welfare of passengers be protected in the operation of pedicabs and commercial quadricycles. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-276. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial quadricycle means a vehicle that is defined in PA 127 of 2015. 
    Operating permit means a written permit issued by the city manager or designee authorizing a person to operate a pedicab or commercial quadricycle. 
    Pedicab means a multiwheeled passenger vehicle that is moved by human power that is pulled, pushed, or otherwise propelled by a person, which is used in the movement of passengers on public rights-of-way and shall include vehicles pulled or pushed directly by human power and vehicles propelled through a cycle or other mechanical means. Pedicab shall include, but not be limited to, cycle rickshaws, cyclos, geotaxis, trishaws, bike taxis, and other pushcart or rickshaw-type vehicles. 
    Pedicab driver means a person who operates a pedicab. 
    Pedicab owner means a person, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or other such business entity that is the owner of a pedicab or a proprietor of a pedicab business who supplies pedicabs to others to operate as independent contractors or employees. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-277. - Prohibition on the operation of pedicabs and commercial quadricycles. 
    No person shall drive or operate a pedicab or commercial quadricycle upon the streets, highways, or thoroughfares of the city, and no person who owns or controls a pedicab or commercial quadricycle shall permit it to be so driven or operated without an operating permit issued by the city. Pedicabs and commercial quadricycles shall be driven or operated in strict compliance with all of the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-278. - Application for operating permit. 
(a)  The city manager or designee shall issue operating permits for pedicabs and commercial quadricycles. Every person desiring to obtain an operating permit is required to make written application for a permit to the city manager or designee on forms provided by the city manager or designee. The applicant shall truthfully and fully provide the information requested on the application, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  The applicant's full name and residence address; 
(2)  The applicant's date of birth; 
(3)  The applicant's driver's license and number; 
(4)  The name of any business entity applying for an operating permit; 
(5)  A certificate of insurance satisfying the requirements of section 110-284; 
(6)  A map of the city showing proposed routes, stands, or pick up points; 
(7)  A list of each authorized pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver, including name, address, date of birth, driver's license number, the length of time such driver has been a resident of Michigan, and certification that the driver has completed the required training programs established by this article; 
(8)  A description of the pedicab and/or commercial quadricycle, including trade name, number of seats, serial number, if any, and body style; and 
(9)  Such other material as the city manager or designee may require. 
(b)  If the applicant is a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or other such business entity, the person who will be acting as principal in charge of the business to be licensed shall sign the application, and all owners of the business entity shall meet all of the requirement for individual applicants. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-279. - Review of application. 
(a)  Upon filing of the application for an operating permit, the city manager or his designee shall review and evaluate the application. In determining whether a permit should be issued, the city manager or his designee shall evaluate whether the application and the applicant meet all of the following: 
(1)  Whether the proposed activities comply with all of the provisions of this article and the code; 
(2)  Whether the proposed activities involve the safe use of streets by the public for vehicles and pedestrians; 
(3)  Whether the applicant has not previously violated the provisions of this article or the code. 
(b)  The police department shall review the application to determine if it satisfies the requirements of this article. 
(c)  If the permit is not approved, the applicant may file an appeal with the city manager or designee. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-280. - Validity of operating permit. 
(a)  Operating permits shall expire on December 31 of each year. 
(b)  The holder of an operating permit may renew an operating permit for the ensuing year with the city manager or designee if in compliance with this article. In order to obtain a renewal, the operating permit holder shall submit such information and fees as shall be required by the city manager or designee. 
(c)  Operating permits shall become invalid immediately if the operating permit is defaced, altered, forged, or counterfeited. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-281. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for an operating permit under this article shall be those fees on file with the city manager or designee which have been approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-282. - Operating regulations. 
(a)  Pedicabs and commercial quadricycles are only permitted to be driven or operated in the city on streets, highways, or thoroughfares designated by the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  If a pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner desires that a person drive a pedicab or commercial quadricycle and such person was not listed in the application described above, the owner shall submit the information provided for in section 110-278 to the city manager or designee. The city manager or designee shall review the information as provided previously and approve or deny such request. 
(c)  No person under the age of 18 shall operate a pedicab or commercial quadricycle. 
(d)  No person shall operate a pedicab or commercial quadricycle unless that person has a valid driver's license. 
(e)  No person shall operate, or cause to be operated, a pedicab or commercial quadricycle in an unsafe manner. 
(f)  All pedicab and commercial quadricycle drivers are subject to all applicable traffic laws, rules, and regulations of the city and the state. 
(g)  All pedicab and commercial quadricycle drivers shall wear respectable attire and a shirt that includes the name of the pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner. 
(h)  Pedicabs and commercial quadricycles are not permitted to park on streets, highways, or thoroughfares except as follows: 
(1)  At a portion of a street that may be designated as a "pedicab or commercial quadricycle stand" for the parking of pedicabs or commercial quadricycles. 
(2)  A single pedicab or commercial quadricycle may park temporarily at the curb or on a sidewalk only as long as necessary for passengers to board and exit the vehicle. 
(3)  In all cases, pedicabs and commercial quadricycles shall be parked in a location that does not impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(i)  No person shall use or allow any pedicab or commercial quadricycle to be used for any illegal purpose. No person shall use or permit or allow any pedicab or commercial quadricycle to be used in, or to aid or abet, any illegal act. 
(j)  No personal shall operate or knowingly permit any other person to operate any pedicab or commercial quadricycle under the influence of intoxicating liquor, any controlled, exhilarating, or stupefying substance, or of any combination of substances mentioned herein. 
(k)  No person shall operate a pedicab or commercial quadricycle when the number of passengers exceeds the number of available seats. No person shall operate a pedicab or commercial quadricycle unless all passengers are seated in a seat designed for that purpose and using the seatbelt provided for in the seat. 
(l)  Each pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner shall adopt and operate a system for the collection, storage, and return of personal property left in a pedicab or commercial quadricycle. 
(m)  The dates of operation of a pedicab or commercial quadricycle shall be limited to April 1 through October 31. 
(n)  The hours of operation of a commercial quadricycle shall be from 11:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. and 6:30 p.m. to 12:00 a.m. The hours of operation of a pedicab shall be determined by the city manager or designee. 
(o)  No pedicab or commercial quadricycle shall be stored on any public property overnight, including but not limited to: streets; alleys; garages; or parking lots. 
(p)  No pedicab or commercial quadricycle shall be operated in the city when in conflict with a special event that has road closures on the streets, highways or thoroughfares designated by the city manager or designee pursuant to subsection (a). 
(q)  The city manager or his designee may impose such other regulations or restrictions on the pedicab or commercial quadricycle operator and owner as they deem appropriate to further the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-283. - Consumption of alcohol. 
    No person shall consume or possess in a container which is open, uncapped, or upon which the seal is broken, alcoholic beverages within or on a pedicab or commercial quadricycle. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-284. - Vehicle regulations. 
(a)  All pedicab and commercial quadricycle vehicles must be constructed for and have the structural integrity to support pedicab or commercial quadricycle operations. Each pedicab or commercial quadricycle vehicle must be equipped with the following: 
(1)  Front and rear turn signals; 
(2)  Headlights; 
(3)  Taillights; 
(4)  Rearview mirror; 
(5)  A bell or horn; 
(6)  Seatbelts; 
(7)  Reflectors placed on each wheel and at each corner of the body of the pedicab or commercial quadricycle; 
(8)  A proper braking systems; 
(9)  Any other equipment required to comply with all applicable federal and state law; and 
(10)  A pedicab or commercial quadricycle must not have any cracks, broken or missing parts, or other visible damage. All wheels must be firmly attached to the hub of a vehicle and all springs, axles, and supporting structures of each pedicab or commercial quadricycle must be intact. 
(b)  Each pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver at all times shall keep each pedicab or commercial quadricycle vehicle clean and free of refuse and in safe operating condition. Prior to the operation of any pedicab or commercial quadricycle and at the beginning of each shift or each day of operation, the pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver shall thoroughly inspect the pedicab or commercial quadricycle for safe operating conditions and shall maintain records of such inspection if required by the city. For any condition found then or at any other time that will prevent the safe operation of the pedicab or commercial quadricycle, the pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver shall immediately remove the pedicab or commercial quadricycle from service and correct the condition before the pedicab or commercial quadricycle is in operating service. 
(c)  Each pedicab or commercial quadricycle shall have a unique, nontransferable vehicle identification number at least four inches in height, visible on both sides of the vehicle. 
(d)  Each pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner shall prepare a training program for pedicab or commercial quadricycle drivers covering, at a minimum, the safe operation of pedicab or commercial quadricycle vehicles, customer service policies, and the requirements of this chapter. 
(e)  Each pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner shall maintain at all times a policy of liability insurance in the minimum amount of $2,000,000.00 for personal injuries and property damage, listing the city as an additional insured, or such amounts as required by state law should the state law minimum amount be higher. Each owner shall further agree to hold the city harmless for any liability or claim arising out of the operation that is not covered by the required insurance. 
(f)  If a pedicab or commercial quadricycle vehicle is involved in an accident or collision, the pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver shall immediately notify the pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner and the department of public safety and remain at the scene until the police investigate the accident or collision. 
(g)  All pedicab or commercial quadricycle drivers must display an identification badge. Each identification badge must contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, and 
(2)  Photograph. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-285. - Grounds for suspension or revocation of operating permit or decal. 
    Operating permits may be denied, suspended, or revoked by the city based upon any of the following grounds: 
(1)  The pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner of a pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver fails or has failed to comply with any provisions of this article. 
(2)  A pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver has been convicted of any felony; reckless driving or driving under the influence offense; or any crime reasonably related to the qualifications, functions, or duties of the passenger transport business or the ability of the pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver to safely transport passengers; unless five years has elapsed from the successful completion of the sentence for any such conviction. 
(3)  A pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver has been convicted of a crime that requires registration under the Michigan Penal Code as a sex offender. 
(4)  A pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver or the pedicab or commercial quadricycle owner has knowingly made a false statement of material fact, or knowingly failed to state a material fact in the application process for the operating permit or decal. 
(5)  A pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver's ability to drive lawfully in Michigan or in any other state is currently expired, suspended, or revoked. 
(6)  A pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver has engaged in activity that, in the judgment of the city manager or designee, constitutes a serious threat to public health, safety, or welfare. Such threat may be indicated by, but is not limited to: 
a.  An arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol or a controlled substance while operating a pedicab or commercial quadricycle; 
b.  An arrest for a crime that, if convicted, would require registration as a sex offender, and where a pedicab or commercial quadricycle was used in the planning of, perpetration of, or fleeing from the offense; 
c.  A report from a law enforcement agency that the pedicab or commercial quadricycle driver was involved in a vehicle accident involving a pedicab or commercial quadricycle, where the pedicab or commercial quadricycle passengers were injured. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-286. - Notification of suspension or revocation of operating permit; appeals. 
(a)  Any operating permit issued by the city may be suspended or revoked by the issuing officer for cause as herein defined. In either case, a hearing shall be scheduled to be held by the city manager or the city manager's designee. Depending upon the necessity for prompt action, the hearing shall be held in accordance with one of the following provisions: 
(1)  If there is no immediate threat to the public health, safety or welfare, the hearing shall be held to determine whether the operating permit should be suspended or revoked. The holder of the operating permit shall be notified of the time, date and place of the hearing and shall be notified of the reason or reasons for the proposed suspension or revocation. The operating permit holder shall be entitled to be represented by counsel, to submit evidence, to cross- examine testifying witnesses, and to make arguments concerning the factual and legal issues. The hearing officer or body shall render a written decision stating the reasons for the decision. 
(2)  If there is an immediate threat to the public health, safety or welfare, the operating permit may be suspended prior to the hearing. If an operating permit is suspended prior to the hearing, the hearing shall be commenced as soon as it is practical, but in no case more than ten days after the suspension. The hearing shall be held to determine whether to terminate or extend the suspension or whether the suspension should be converted into a revocation of the operating permit. The holder of the operating permit shall be notified of the time, date, and place of the hearing and shall be notified of the reason or reasons for the already-imposed suspension and for any contemplated future action. The operating permit holder shall be entitled to be represented by counsel, to submit evidence, to cross-examine testifying witnesses, and to make arguments on factual and legal issues. The hearing officer or body shall render a written decision stating the reasons for the decision. 
(b)  If any hearing held pursuant to the provisions of this article, the rules of evidence shall be followed as far as practicable, but a hearing officer or body may admit and give probative effect to evidence of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent people in the conduct of their affairs. Irrelevant, immaterial or unduly repetitious evidence may be excluded. Notice may be taken of facts within the general knowledge of the community. A record of the hearing shall be maintained by the hearing officer or body. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-287. - Preliminary breath test. 
    A city police department officer who has reasonable cause to believe that the operator of a pedicab or commercial quadricycle who is or was operating a pedicab or commercial quadricycle upon a public highway or other place open to the public or generally accessible to a pedicab or commercial quadricycle, including an area designated for the parking of vehicles, and that the operator by the consumption of alcoholic liquor may have affected his or her ability to operate the pedicab or commercial quadricycle may require the operator to submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis. A pedicab or commercial quadricycle operator's refusal to take or failure to properly take a preliminary chemical breath analysis as required by this section is a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Sec. 110-288. - Violation is a civil infraction. 
    Any violation of this article shall be a municipal civil infraction as provided for in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2157, 9-10-15) 
Chapter 114 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; planning, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; subdivisions, ch. 102; zoning, ch. 126. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 114-1-114-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 114-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Department means the department of water supply of the city. 
    Main means any pipes, other than service pipes, used for conveying or distributing water. 
    Owner means any person owning any premises supplied or to be supplied with city water, or his duly authorized agent. 
    Premises means a single dwelling or apartment occupied by one family only, together with the land connected therewith and such outbuildings as are used exclusively in connection therewith, or a single room or number of rooms or building occupied for business or other purposes by one person. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the department, as designated in section 2-128. 
    Water service pipe means the pipe tapped into the water main and extending thence to the meter, including appurtenances connected thereto. 
(Code 1963, § 2.20) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 114-27. - Main extensions. 
    Extension of, or changes in, the water mains shall be made only by direction of the city commission. Petitions for the extensions of old or construction of new mains shall be addressed to the commission. If the petition is granted, the commission shall determine the proportions of the cost to be borne by the petitioners and by the department. 
(Code 1963, § 2.21) 
Sec. 114-28. - Installation of mains. 
    Any person installing water mains at his own expense shall first submit plans and specifications for such work to the city engineer for approval. After such plans and specifications have been approved, the work shall be done under the supervision of the superintendent who shall require such tests made as he considers necessary and shall accept the installation for the city before the water is admitted to such mains. All inspection costs for such installation shall be paid by the party installing the water main. The provisions of this section shall also apply to any installations of water mains outside the corporate limits of the city where permission has been granted by the city commission to connect to the department mains. 
(Code 1963, § 2.22) 
Sec. 114-29. - Trenching. 
    All water service pipe on either public or private property shall be laid on a solid bottom not less than four feet, six inches, below the established grade. Water service pipe laid in the same trench with a sewer shall be above and at least 18 inches distant from the sewer and shall be shelved into the bank. In no case shall water service pipe be laid on a fill. 
(Code 1963, § 2.25) 
Sec. 114-30. - Pipe specifications. 
    All water service pipe from the main to the meter shall be copper pipe (Type K) or pipe of equal quality approved by the water department and not less than one inch inside diameter. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in cases where special and unusual circumstances indicate that substantially equivalent service can be provided by smaller pipe, the superintendent may authorize the installation of service pipe of not less than three-fourths inch inside diameter. All stop or service cocks shall be the same size as the service pipe and shall be extra heavy, round way stops. The stop cock and stop box shall, when practical, be placed on the property line. The stop cocks and stop boxes shall be placed 18 inches inside the face of the curb when, in the opinion of the water department, it is impractical to locate these boxes on the property line. 
(Code 1963, § 2.26) 
Sec. 114-31. - Service pipe, stop cock and stop box; installation and maintenance. 
    The water service pipe from the main to the stop cock, also the stop cock and the stop box, will be furnished, installed and maintained by the department except as provided in this article. In those cases where the extension of service to the building is not installed prior to the installation by the city of the service from the street to the property line, it shall be the responsibility of the plumber to install and maintain such stop box until the final inspection by the building official. The owner shall see that the box is kept free of dirt, stones or other substances at all times. 
(Code 1963, § 2.27) 
Sec. 114-32. - Installation permit. 
    Upon the securing of a permit therefor, the water service pipe shall be installed in the owner's property by a licensed plumber registered in the city. All water service pipe on private property shall be maintained by the owner of the premises. 
(Code 1963, § 2.28) 
Sec. 114-33. - Inspection. 
    The water service from the property line to the building shall be inspected and approved by the plumbing inspector. In all cases where services are not properly installed, thereby necessitating an additional inspection, there shall be an additional charge for each inspection, in accordance with section 114-40. 
(Code 1963, § 2.29) 
Sec. 114-34. - Testing work. 
    Licensed plumbers shall not interfere in any way with water service pipes installed by the department, and are not permitted to turn water on or off at the stop cock except for the purpose of testing their work, in which case the stop cock shall be left in the same condition and position as they found it. Any plumber called upon to shut off water and drain pipes in any premises shall do so inside the building only. The license of any plumber violating the provisions of this section may be revoked. 
(Code 1963, § 2.30) 
Sec. 114-35. - Gate valves. 
    Separate gate valves the same size as the service pipe must be placed on the water service pipe on both sides of the meter. Such valves shall be equal in quality to the service cock. 
(Code 1963, § 2.31) 
Sec. 114-36. - Repair existing pipe. 
    All iron water service pipe requiring repairs shall be replaced by copper under the same regulations as required for new services. Under no conditions shall iron water service pipe be repaired. Upon the appearance of a leak in any such water service pipe, the owner of the premises shall immediately pay the department for the installation of pipe from the main to the stop cock and the department will install same. The owner shall also cause the balance of the iron pipe to be replaced with copper before the water will be turned on. 
(Code 1963, § 2.32) 
Sec. 114-37. - Alternate material and construction. 
    The regulations contained in this article specifying certain materials and methods of construction shall not act to eliminate other materials or methods of construction which are equivalent to or better than the materials and methods of construction specified. The superintendent is hereby authorized to approve other materials and methods of construction when it is necessary or advisable to use such substitute materials and methods of construction. 
(Code 1963, § 2.33) 
Sec. 114-38. - Meters required. 
    All premises using department water shall be metered. In no case will water be supplied at fixed rates or in any manner not requiring a meter, except for a temporary supply. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, for any new construction commencing on or after July 1, 2007, if the building has both residential and nonresidential uses, there must be separate water meter service for the residential and nonresidential users such that the use by nonresidential customers can be separately metered and billed so that industrial waste control charges and/or industrial surcharges may be applied to those nonresidential users. In addition, owners of an existing building with single water meter for both residential and nonresidential users may choose to install separate meters so that the industrial waste control charges may be assessed only to the nonresidential users. Should a building owner, whose buildings do not have separate water service for residential and nonresidential, choose not to install separate meters, the building owner shall be required to pay the industrial waste control charges based upon the total service to the building. For purposes of this section, nonresidential users shall be defined as all users other than single-family houses, apartment buildings, residential condominiums, townhouses, mobile homes, schools, churches and municipal buildings. 
(Code 1963, § 2.37; Ord. No. 1930, 5-14-07) 
Sec. 114-39. - Installation charge. 
    The property owner shall pay the cost of the water meter furnished by the department, but such meter shall remain the property of the department and will at all times be under its control. 
(Code 1963, § 2.38) 
Sec. 114-40. - Cost of repairs. 
    The expense of installing and maintaining meters will be borne by the department; but where replacements, repairs or adjustments of the meter are made necessary by the act, neglect or carelessness of the owner or occupant of any premises, the expense to the department caused thereby may be charged against and collected from the owner or occupant of the premises. 
(Code 1963, § 2.39) 
Sec. 114-41. - Size of meters. 
    For ordinary domestic consumption of water a five-eighths-inch meter will be furnished. Where application is made for a meter larger than one inch, the superintendent shall determine whether a meter of such size is required, and the probable effect upon the water and sewage system as a whole; and he is hereby vested with the sole discretion of approving or disapproving the same. All meters 11/2 inches or over must have a bypass as required by the superintendent. 
(Code 1963, § 2.40) 
Sec. 114-42. - Meter location. 
(a)  Meters shall be set in accessible locations and in a manner satisfactory to the superintendent. Meters shall be set as close as practicable to the point where the water service pipe enters the building. In no case shall a meter be set where it is liable to injury or where it cannot readily be reached by the meter reader. The portion of the water service pipe between its entrance into the building and the meter shall be installed and maintained in a manner to make it accessible for inspection by the city at any time. 
(b)  A meter shall be placed in a pit rather than in the building being served when the superintendent determines that placement of the meter within a building would work an unusual hardship on the property owner or on the department. The superintendent may require that a meter be placed in a pit: 
(1)  Where the distance from the water main to the building is more than 200 feet; or 
(2)  Where the superintendent determines that due to the nature of the installation there is a greater than normal potential for control problems or leaks developing in the service pipe. 
(c)  Placement of a meter in a pit shall be done in accordance with the requirements of the superintendent and at the sole expense of the owner. 
(Code 1963, § 2.41) 
Sec. 114-43. - Seal, tampering with meter. 
    Meters will be sealed by the department, and no one except an authorized employee of the department shall break or injure such seals. No person unless authorized by the department shall change the location of, alter or interfere in any way with any meter. After installation, no obstruction shall be placed adjacent to the meter that will prevent its accessibility. 
(Code 1963, § 2.42) 
Sec. 114-44. - Injury to meter. 
    The owner or occupant of any premises where a meter is installed will be held responsible for its care and protection from freezing, and from injury or interference by any person. In case of injury to the meter, or in case of its stoppage or imperfect working, he shall give immediate notice to the department. 
(Code 1963, § 2.43) 
Sec. 114-45. - Accuracy of meters. 
    If any meter becomes out of order and fails to register, the consumer will be charged at the quarterly consumption based on the same quarter for the previous year. The accuracy of the meter on any premises will be tested by the department upon written request of the owner. If on such test the meter shall be found to register over three percent more water than actually passes through it, another meter will be substituted therefor and the water bill may be adjusted in such manner as may be fair and just. 
(Code 1963, § 2.44) 
Sec. 114-46. - Fire-line installations. 
    In a fire-line installation, a detector check meter is required. 
(Code 1963, § 2.45) 
Sec. 114-47. - Remote register installations. 
    Remote water meter registers, where installed, shall be considered as part of the water meter required under this article. Remote water meter registers shall be installed in accordance with a policy established by the city commission. 
(Code 1963, § 2.46) 
Sec. 114-48. - Application. 
    Before any connection shall be made to any water main, application for same shall be made in writing to the department by the owner of the premises or by his authorized agent. Such application shall be made on blank forms provided by the department. In making such application the owner shall agree to abide by all the rules and regulations of the department, including the payment for water furnished. 
(Code 1963, § 2.51) 
Sec. 114-49. - Location of service. 
    The location of the service at the property line will be as designated by the owner unless there are, in the opinion of the department, reasons for changing the same. 
(Code 1963, § 2.52) 
Sec. 114-50. - Connection fee. 
    No connection shall be made, nor shall any existing connection to the water system be replaced until the applicant therefor has paid such fee as is established by the city commission. The city commission shall establish a schedule of fees for connections to the water system of the city, and any inspection costs or charges incurred by the city in connection therewith. 
(Code 1963, § 2.53) 
Sec. 114-51. - Outside service. 
    Property owners not within the city corporate limits may connect into the city water mains only upon the approval of the city commission. All connections shall comply with the city's specifications for construction of water mains, services and appurtenances. 
(Code 1963, § 2.54) 
Sec. 114-52. - Service during construction. 
    At the time application is made for a water service connection to a building under construction, the owner shall pay to the department, in addition to the fee provided in section 114-50 such fees for the water used in construction as are established by the commission. The construction fee shall entitle the applicant to water for construction purposes for a period of not more than three months. The department reserves the right to require the owner to provide a temporary meter connection and to charge for water used for construction purposes at the rates provided for in this chapter. Such meter shall be protected by the owner, and any damage it may sustain shall be repaired at his expense. Where water is provided without a meter, for construction of a building, any wasting of water for landscaping or purpose other than construction may result in discontinuance of the service and the payment of additional charges. 
(Code 1963, § 2.55) 
Sec. 114-53. - Construction service; deposit. 
    At the time application is made for a service connection to a building under construction, the applicant shall deposit with the city treasurer the sum set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance to guarantee maintenance during the construction period of the water stop box, which sum shall be retained by the city until final inspection of the premises by the plumbing inspector, and until the plumbing inspector shall determine that the stop box has been properly maintained and set to finish grade. If the plumbing inspector shall determine that the stop box does not pass inspection, the city shall correct the same and apply the full deposit for the services so rendered. 
(Code 1963, § 2.56; Ord. No. 1507, § 2.56, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 114-54. - Multiple service. 
    A single water service shall not serve several premises under separate ownerships unless the owners of such premises, by common agreement or otherwise, make arrangements for installations, metering, billing and discontinuance of service to such premises which are satisfactory to the superintendent of the water department. A building under one ownership consisting of several premises may be served by one or more water services and meters, but in no case shall the number of water services and meters exceed the number of premises. Two or more adjacent buildings under common ownership may have a separate water service and meter for each principal building. When more than one meter is served by one water service, all meters served by the service must operate from a manifold type arrangement. Failure of one unit in the manifold arrangement to pay for water received will result in a discontinuance of water to that meter. In multiple installations, no totalizing meter will be installed or read by the department. In addition to each water service allowed under this section, one separate fire line service is allowed. Where multiple premises are consolidated to result in less premises and more than one water service to a premises, such additional services may continue to be used with the approval of the superintendent. In cases where it is impractical to provide water service in accordance with the requirements of this article, the superintendent may authorize one or more additional water service connections for a premises. Cross connections between water service pipes are prohibited. 
(Code 1963, § 2.57) 
Sec. 114-55. - Converted multiple premises. 
    Where a building originally built as a single building or premises and fitted with one service pipe shall thereafter be subdivided and such subdivision shall be separately owned, the separate divisions so made must be connected to the main by separate service pipes, or otherwise modified to meet the requirements of section 114-54, within 30 days after such division. 
(Code 1963, § 2.58) 
Sec. 114-56. - Disconnection of water services. 
    All water service pipes, which are not to be used as a result of conversion of multiple premises, building changes, service replacement, or for any other reasons shall be disconnected at the main. The owner shall obtain a permit from the city and shall pay for the disconnection charge set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance for every service pipe disconnected. Application for the permit shall be made within 30 days after the discontinuation of use of the service. A water service pipe which serves a building or portion of a building which is to be removed, and which meets City Code requirements for a new service pipe may be reused for a new building with the approval of the superintendent. No charge will be made by the city for a water service pipe to be reused in a new building. No charge will be made for a meter reused in a new building provided a building permit is applied for no more than one year following the removal of the building or portion of building; and further provided the meter is the same size as the one removed. A disconnection permit will not be required and there will be no disconnection charge in conjunction with a water service replacement, if the service location is unchanged at the property line, or the water department determines it is practical to connect the replacement service to the main at the location where the old service is to be discontinued. 
(Code 1963, § 2.59; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 114-57. - Meter removal, replacement, special service. 
(a)  A charge as set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance shall be made by the department for customer requested removal and replacement of any water meter, except there will be no charge for removing and replacing a water meter that is removed and tested in accordance with section 114-45, where on such test the meter is found to register over three percent more water than actually passes through it. 
(b)  A charge as set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance shall be made by this department for customer requested service performed at times other than within the normal seasonal working hours of the department, Monday through Friday, excluding holidays. 
(c)  Such service work shall include shutting off water, turning on water and repairing or replacing damaged meters. 
(Code 1963, § 2.60; Ord. No. 1748, 11-27-00; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 114-58. - Backyard water main abandonment. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is the protection of health, safety and public welfare by authorizing the city's director of engineering department to develop a written procedure and take the necessary actions to abandon any water mains currently located in the rear yard and require the affected residents to connect to the water main system either currently existing, or that which will be constructed, in the city street. The city has determined that the rear yard water mains should be abandoned and no longer used for several reasons including, but not limited to, that said water mains are nearing or have exceeded the end of their service life; are increasingly in need of repairs as they age; subject to corrosion; pipe failure causing damage to private rear yard improvements such as trees, landscaping and garages that are located over or near the water main; corrective action when repairing/replacing water mains causing damage to same. In addition, existing rear yard water mains are typically smaller than current standards require. Existing mains typically have reduced flow due to internal sedimentation and tuberculin buildup on the inside pipe walls. Fire hydrants are not accessible or effective if located in the rear yard. 
(b)  Procedure to be developed. The city engineering department shall develop a procedure for the abandonment of the rear yard water mains and set forth the requirements for disconnecting from the rear yard water mains and for connection to the water main located, or to be located, in the city street. Said procedure shall include the procedure, requirements and timing of disconnection and connection. 
(c)  Procedure approval. The procedure developed, or any amendment thereto, shall not become effective until approved by the city commission. The approved procedure and all subsequent amendments approved by the city commission shall be incorporated herein by reference. A copy of the approved procedure and any amendments thereto, shall be sent to all properties currently serviced by a rear yard water main. A copy of the approved procedure shall also be available for review at the city's engineering department during normal business hours. 
(d)  Connection and disconnection required. The owners of all houses, buildings or properties currently serviced by a rear yard water main are hereby required, at the owner's own expense, to arrange for and complete the connection to the water stop box provided by the city at or near the front of the property and disconnect from the rear yard main as required and within the time frames set forth in the approved procedure, including obtaining the necessary permits, paying the appropriate fees and obtaining city inspections and approvals for said work as set forth in the city's ordinances. 
(e)  Penalty for non-compliance. 
(1)  Any person who fails to disconnect and connect as set forth in this section and the approved procedure shall be considered in violation of this ordinance and shall be subject to a fine of no less than $100.00 per offense. 
(2)  Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. The rights and remedies set forth for violations of this section are cumulative and in addition to any other remedies provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1855, 1-10-05) 
Secs. 114-59-114-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - USE 

Sec. 114-71. - Initial service. 
    When new water service pipes are put into any premises, the stop cock shall be left closed and will thereafter be opened by the department only upon request of the owner or his agent. The holder of a permit for temporary use of water shall notify the department upon completion of his work so that the water may be shut off. 
(Code 1963, § 2.61) 
Sec. 114-72. - Furnishing other premises. 
(a)  No person shall take or use department water from premises other than his own and no person shall sell or give away department water from his own premises for any purpose without written permission from the department. Where such permission is granted, the collection of amounts due the property owner shall be his responsibility. 
(b)  Water shall be taken and used only through water service pipes under the supervision of the department and no connection through which water may pass from one property to another shall exist even though the ownership of both properties may be the same. 
(Code 1963, § 2.62) 
Sec. 114-73. - Water waste. 
    Excessive or unnecessary use or waste of water, whether caused by carelessness or by defective or leaky plumbing or fixtures, is strictly prohibited. For disregard or repeated violation of this requirement, the water may be turned off by the department. 
(Code 1963, § 2.63) 
Sec. 114-74. - Reconnection after termination. 
    Where the water has been turned off by the department of any reason, no person or persons except authorized employees or agents of the department may turn it on again. 
(Code 1963, § 2.64) 
Sec. 114-75. - Boiler connections. 
    No steam engine boilers shall be directly connected to the water service pipe. The owner shall provide a tank of sufficient capacity to afford a supply for at least ten hours, into which the service pipe shall discharge. 
(Code 1963, § 2.65) 
Sec. 114-76. - Water use reduction emergency. 
    No person shall make any outdoor use from the public water supply except in response to a fire emergency in any area designated within the city during a water use reduction emergency. The owner of the property on which the water meter being utilized for such outdoor use is located or any person in control of such property shall be responsible for any violation of this section. 
(1)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section: 
a.  SOCWA means the Southeastern Oakland County Water Authority. 
b.  Water use reduction emergency means a situation where SOCWA determines the water usage from the water distribution system is of such volume that, unless restricted, the public health, safety and general welfare are likely to be endangered. 
(2)  Declaration. Whenever SOCWA determines that the public health, safety and welfare are endangered based on: 
a.  A prolonged drought or other period of system-wide heavy demand that results in supply facilities, including system pump stations and reservoirs, being operated at their optimum capacity with no apparent means immediately available to adequately maintain flows and residual pressures throughout the system, or 
b.  Any emergency condition which may adversely affect operating flows and residual pressures in any substantial portion of the system for any appreciable length of time, SOCWA shall put into effect a water use reduction emergency for all or any part or parts of the city by declaring it in a manner prescribed in this section. 
(3)  Duration. A water use reduction emergency, once declared in accordance with this section, shall remain in effect 24 hours per day, seven days per week until SOCWA has declared an end to the water use reduction emergency or SOCWA determines that a limited prohibition will be sufficient to protect the health, safety and general welfare of the community. Upon such determination, SOCWA may establish a water use reduction schedule for all or any part of the city during which outdoor use of water for nonfire emergency uses during a water use reduction emergency shall be allowed. If such a water use reduction schedule is established, outdoor nonfire emergency use of water which does not comply with SOCWA's established schedule shall be a violation of the provisions of this section. 
(4)  Notice. Upon declaration of such water use reduction emergency, SOCWA shall cause public announcement of such emergency by means of broadcasts and/or telecasts from various commercial stations serving the city and/or on the public access channel of any cable franchisee servicing the city, and may cause the ban to be further announced in newspapers of general circulation where feasible. 
(5)  Enforcement. 
a.  Members of the police department are hereby authorized to issue ordinance violation notices to any person violating any provision of this section or any rule or regulation duly adopted in pursuance of this section. 
b.  The city manager or his designee shall implement whatever reductions are necessary to meet the water use reduction emergency requirements. 
(6)  Exemptions. The city manager or his designee may exempt a property or properties from the operation of this section where necessary to prevent imminent and disastrous financial loss to a water user. 
(7)  Penalties. In addition to all other penalties available for the violation of this section, any person who violates this section shall be responsible for any cost involved in shutting off the water to the property on which the water meter for the water being used in violation of the emergency is located. 
(Ord. No. 1601, 9-12-94) 
Sec. 114-77. - Air conditioning. 
    No person shall use any air conditioning or cooling machinery or apparatus which at any period consumes water in excess of ten gallons per minute, unless such air conditioning or cooling machinery or apparatus is equipped with a cooling tower, or other equipment which the superintendent has determined is approximately as effective in conserving water as a cooling tower. All air conditioning or cooling machinery or apparatus shall be designed and maintained to prevent excessive or unnecessary use or waste of water and shall comply with the provisions of section 114-73. 
(Code 1963, § 2.67) 
Sec. 114-78. - Lawn sprinkling systems. 
    Automatic sprinkling systems for watering grounds must not be installed in such manner as to cause the spray to spread over the sidewalk. 
(Code 1963, § 2.75) 
Secs. 114-79-114-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIRE PROTECTION 

Sec. 114-91. - Connections. 
    Where hose connections for fire apparatus are provided on any pipe, each connection or opening on such pipes shall have not less than 25 feet of fire hose constantly attached thereto, and no water shall be taken through such openings or hose for any purposes other than for extinguishing fires or testing fire equipment. Any such test must be conducted under a special permit and under the supervision of the department. Fire lines must be metered as provided for in section 114-46. 
(Code 1963, § 2.81) 
Sec. 114-92. - Fire hydrants. 
    Fire hydrants are to be opened and used only by authorized city personnel. Any person desiring to use any fire hydrant in the city must apply for a permit to use the same specifying what hydrants are to be used and for what purpose, pay the permit fee set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance, and deposit with the city treasurer the sum set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance. Such person must report to the fire department when such use is terminated, at which time a hydrant inspection will be made and the cost of reconditioning of such hydrant shall be deducted from the deposit and the difference less a charge established by the superintendent for the water used shall be refunded to the depositor. 
(Code 1963, § 2.82; Ord. No. 1507, § 2.82, 11-25-91; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Sec. 114-93. - Obstructing hydrants. 
    No person shall in any manner obstruct or prevent free access to any fire hydrant by placing or storing temporarily or otherwise any object, material, snow, debris or structure of any kind, within a distance of 15 feet from same. 
(Code 1963, § 2.83) 
Secs. 114-94-114-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTION AND REPAIRS 

Sec. 114-106. - Access to premises. 
    Any officer, inspector, foreman, or other authorized employee of the department shall have free access at all reasonable hours to any property or premises supplied with department water for the purpose of making an inspection thereof, including the examination of the entire water supply and plumbing system on such premises and for installing, adjusting, repairing, replacing or reading a water meter or a remote water meter register, and for measurement, sampling, or testing of any part of the plumbing connected to the water system. 
(Code 1963, § 2.84; Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98) 
Sec. 114-107. - Suspension of service. 
    In case any owner or occupant of any property or premises refuses or fails to arrange for a suitable time for inspection, or an authorized employee be refused admittance to any property or premises, or being admitted shall be hindered or prevented in making such examination, or installing, adjusting, repairing, replacing or reading a water meter, or a remote water meter register, or measuring, sampling or testing any part of the plumbing connected to the water system, the water may be turned off from such premises upon 24 hours' notice to the owner or occupant thereof. 
(Code 1963, § 2.84; Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98) 
Sec. 114-108. - Shut-off for repairs. 
    Should it become necessary to shut off the water to any section of the city because of accidents or for the purpose of making repairs or extensions, the department will endeavor to give timely notice to the consumers affected thereby, and will, so far as practical, use its best efforts to prevent inconvenience and damage arising from any such causes, but failure to give such notice shall not render the department responsible or liable for damages that may result therefrom, or for any other cause. 
(Code 1963, § 2.85; Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98) 
Secs. 114-109-114-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CROSS CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 114-121. - Adoption of rules. 
    The water supply cross connection rules of the state department of public health, being R 325.11401 to R 325.11407 of the Michigan Administrative Code, are hereby adopted by reference by the city. 
(Code 1963, § 2.113; Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98) 
Sec. 114-122. - Prohibited. 
    Cross connections with the city water supply system are prohibited. For the purposes of this division, a cross connection is any connection or arrangement of piping or appurtenances through which water of questionable quality, wastes or other contaminants can enter the city water supply system. 
(Code 1963, § 2.110; Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98) 
Sec. 114-123. - Discontinue water service. 
    The department may discontinue water service after reasonable notice to any property where any cross connection exists in violation of this division, and the department may take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the city water supply system. 
(Code 1963, § 2.111; Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98) 
Sec. 114-124. - Nonpotable water outlets. 
    Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as "Water unsafe for drinking." 
(Code 1963, § 2.112; Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98) 
Sec. 114-125. - Fee for cross connections inspection. 
(a)  There shall be a fee for an initial cross connections inspection, for any subsequent re-inspections, and for any device test report review conducted by the city or its authorized representative to check for the presence of cross connections. No cross connections inspection fees shall be charged for the inspection or re-inspection of single-family residential premises that would be in addition to any fees or costs charged in connection with permits and/or inspections for single-family residential premises in connection with changes to plumbing, sale of the property, restoration of water service, or installation of a water meter. The fees provided for in this section shall be in the amount set forth in the schedule of fees, charges, bonds and insurance. 
(b)  Such fee shall be billed against the owner of the property, and payment due to the city within 30 days of the bill. Such fee shall become a lien against the property immediately upon the completion of any inspection pursuant to this section. 
(c)  Payment shall be due to the city within 30 days of the bill being sent to the property owner for the performance of such services. The bill shall notify the property owner of his or her right to dispute all or any part of the bill before a hearing officer, as established by section 1-17 of this Code, prior to the due date of the bill. Except as otherwise determined by the hearing officer, if payment is not received by the city within 30 days after such billing, the city treasurer shall add an additional penalty of one percent per month to the delinquent bill. The city treasurer shall annually, on May 1, certify any delinquent billing, or any part thereof, together with all accrued interest and penalty, to the commission; and, it shall be transferred and reassessed, with an additional 15 percent penalty, on the next annual city tax roll. Such charges so assessed shall be collected in the same manner as general city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1666, 2-9-98; Ord. No. 1829, 4-19-04; Ord. No. 2010, 2-8-10) 
Secs. 114-126-114-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 114-146. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act or the act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, P.L. 92-500 also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq. 
    Approval authority means the state department of natural resources or the Environmental Protection Agency. 
    As-built plans means engineering drawings prepared after installations of wastewater facilities which shall show a statement by a registered engineer or surveyor certifying them to be as-built plans and shall include, but not be limited to, length of sewer, invert elevation, locations with respect to property lines, wye and riser locations and depths, sewer material and joints used, and mechanical, electrical, and structural details for pump stations, wastewater treatment facilities and other appurtenances. 
    Authorized representative of industrial user refers to: 
(1)  A corporate officer, if the industrial user is a corporation; 
(2)  A general partner or proprietor, if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; or 
(3)  A duly authorized representative of the individual designated in either of the above, if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the indirect discharge originates or is the identified corporation, partnership or proprietorship representative for responding to discharge inquiries or actions. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of dissolved oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure five days at 20 degrees Celsius expressed in terms of weight and concentration [milligrams per liter (mg/l)] as measured by standard methods. 
    Board means the Board of Water Commissioners of the City of Detroit. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building's sewer (house sewer). The latter begins five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain that connects the building in which the sanitary sewage originates to the public sewer or other place of disposal and conveys the sewage of but one building. 
    Categorical standards means the National Categorical Pretreatment Standards or a pretreatment standard as promulgated under authority of the act, 40 CFR 403. 
    Chemical oxygen demand (COD) means a measure of the oxygen-consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in water or wastewater. It is expressed as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specified test. It does not differentiate between stable and unstable organic matter and thus does not necessarily correlate with biochemical oxygen demand. Also known as OC and DOC, oxygen consumed and dichromate oxygen consumed, respectively. 
    Chlorine demand means the difference between the amount of chlorine applied and the amount of free chlorine available at the end of the contact time, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Combination sewer or combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Compatible pollutant means BOD (biochemical oxygen demand), FOG (fats, oils or grease), phosphorus, suspended solids, and fecal coliform bacteria, plus other pollutants which do not exceed the control authority's interference or pass through limitations or the limitations of this article. 
    Composite sample means a series of grab samples of equal volume taken over a specified time period with no regard to the flow in the waste stream which are combined into one sample. The arrangement of the sample series shall be tailored to the specific circumstances of the wastestream being tested and shall reasonably reflect the characteristics of the waste stream at the time of each individual sample. 
    Consent judgment means the judgment issued by Federal District Court on September 14, 1977, U.S. EPA v. City of Detroit, et al, C.A. No. 77- 1100, as amended. 
    Control authority means the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department (DWSD) which has been officially designated as such by the state under the provisions of 40 CFR 403.12 or authorized representatives or employees of the DWSD. 
    Control manhole means a suitable manhole, together with such necessary meters, including where appropriate, adequate power source and other appurtenances, to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of wastewater to be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the county's engineering personnel. 
    County means the County of Oakland, State of Michigan, or its authorized representative, the Detroit Water and Sewerage Department. 
    County agency means the county drain commissioner or the county department of public works. 
    Cooling water shall mean the noncontact water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    Critical materials means the organic and inorganic substances, elements or compounds, listed in the register compiled by the water resources commission of the state department of natural resources. 
    Days means, for purposes of computing a period of time prescribed or allowed by this article, consecutive calendar days. 
    Debt service charge means charges levied to customers of the wastewater system which are used to pay principal, interest and administrative costs of retiring the debt incurred for construction of the wastewater system. The debt service charge is separate and distinct and may be in addition to the user charge specified below. 
    Department means the department of public services. 
    Direct discharge means the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly into the waters of the state. 
    Director means the director of the Detroit Department of Water and Sewerage or the director's deputy. 
    Domestic user means a person who contributes, causes or permits wastewater to be discharged into the publicly-owned treatment works from a place of domicile for one or more persons, including, but not limited to, single-family houses, apartment buildings, condominiums, townhouses and mobile homes. It shall also include churches, schools and government buildings. 
    Dwelling means any structure designed for year-round habitation including, but not limited to, houses, mobile homes, apartment buildings, condominiums and townhouses. 
    Environmental protection agency (EPA) means the United States Environmental Protection Agency or, where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the administrator or other authorized official of such federal agency. 
    Fats, oil, or grease (FOG) means any hydrocarbons, fatty acids, soaps, fats, waxes, oils and any other nonvolatile material of animal, vegetable or mineral origin that is extractable by solvent in accordance with standard methods. 
    Federal grant means a grant made or to be made for the construction of wastewater collection, transportation and/or treatment works provided under the act, P.L. 92-500, as amended. 
    Flow proportional sample means a composite sample taken with regard to the flow rate of the waste stream. 
    Footing drain means a pipe or conduit which is placed around the perimeter of a building foundation and which intentionally admits groundwater. 
    Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. It is composed of putrescible organic matter and its natural moisture content. 
    General specifications means the current edition of standard material and construction requirements of the county.
